Avatar 2 has good action and good cgi, but the lack of logic in the story completely took me out of the film, especially the decisions made by Jake Sully. When his children are put in danger by invading soldiers, he could have called upon his entire tribe to come come together to take them down, which would have ended the conflict of the movie right away. Instead he goes at it alone with Neytiri, which allows the soldiers to get away and prolongs the conflict.

 The entire premise of the movie is also baffling as Jake decides to leave his tribe who he spent the entire first movie fighting beside and instead brings war and suffering to peaceful communities who get put to the torch for this one man. The fact that Jake is being put first over entire communities of peaceful people is very upsetting to watch. This movie depicts the suffering of indigenous people seemingly for the audience to become invested in the story. Yet there are hardly any actual indigenous people including Māori people that the water tribe are based off of in both the cast and crew of this film production. This film depicts indigenous people fictionally but ignores the real life people that they are based on.

Avatar 2 had multiple references to Indigenous cultures from the mannerisms to the association with whales and the facial tattoos, to say that it was purely fictional would be incorrect. Although research may have been done, it should be checked by multiple consultants to ensure there's no exploitation and disrespect. I'm sure this can all be attainable considering how much effort is placed into the accuracy of the CGI work. That same dedication can be placed on the inclusion of culture on and behind the screen.

The CGI was exceptional and felt realistic, which made each scene that much more captivating. I appreciate the thought put into small details to make the movie that much more natural and emotional. The war scenes of everything on fire, the whales being poached, and the ocean being ruined by the colonization of the "sky people" are representative of things that happen throughout our history. Inventing the Na'vi language was impressive and made it so the movie wasn't appropriating.

I would argue that the actors cast to play the indigenous people of Pandora, should also be native or indigenous, and not white. I couldn't understand why some of the characters spoke with an accent while some spoke with perfect English, despite the characters all growing up together speaking the same language. I wish the idea of poaching wasn't also just tossed into the story in a throw-away scene. It would have been more impactful to have either touched on it more or left it out completely. I felt like the story was recycled from the first movie and if it was given as much thought as the CGI and visuals, it would have been a top-tier movie.

I do realize that the whole meaning of the film is to show how bad humanity can be and how we can steal culture and colonize lands, but there should still be structure in the story and more thought to the indigenous culture.

To James Cameron: Many people have been appreciative of the work that you have created and is very evident as it is one of the best-selling films of all time. The film is absolutely gorgeous and is incredible in terms of cinematics. With that being said, many have concluded that the ideas you have formulated are derivative of pre-existing Indigenous cultures, especially the Maori culture. Whether this may have been your intention or not, the criticisms have already been made and it may be in your best interest to try and avoid the recurrence of these critiques moving forward. While the story of the Navi people is not necessarily Indigenous as they are about a group of alien beings who simply do not exist, there are many influences that are apparent in their nature. It would be nice to further nurture such influences if they were directly gathered from more Indigenous people who were featured in the making of these films.

I thought that the film was a very amazing experience on the first watch-through. After seeing the first Avatar film, it's safe to say that Cameron took the effects and visuals to the next level in The Way of the Water. Even with the film's 3-hour runtime, it is clear how much effort he, the cast, and the studio poured in to making the film a reality. While Cameron did strive for maximum authenticity, however, my critique would lie in his representation of other cultures. Even though Pandora is a made-up world, the Polynesian cultures that he pulls from to make the Water Na'vi people can be seen as inauthentic, or even appropriated by some. Given that the writing team had very little representation of those with a Polynesian/Pacific background, it can give the film a skewed view of a very rich, diverse culture. Although the film is still fantasy at the end of the day, I believe that Avatar 2 would have been greatly enhanced if the story was told through the eyes of Pacific writers and crew members, rather than from an outsider's view.

Dear Mr. James Cameron, I'm Zacchaeus Domingo, a young and aspiring filmmaker. I watched your Avatar Way of the Water Movie. It was Great on a technical level, the way you animated the water and characters was phenomenal. The environments were beautifully rendered, the water physics was very realistic, and the creature design was perfect. There are some criticisms of this film, especially regarding how you represented indigenous culture in the movie. You should have more than just one cultural consultant in your film, having just one isn't enough when making a feature film, especially when you pull inspiration from many different indigenous cultures. You should also not call them "Cultural Consultants", bump them up to Producer due to them having a say and influence in the production of the film. Don't ignore what your Cultural Consultants say to you, what they say might be very important, and even though what they say might be very limiting, you still need to hear them out due to them knowing their culture best.

With the release of Avatar 2: The Way of Water, I imagine there must have been a lot of excitement leading up to it as to the audience response of the sequel due to the fact that the first film was the highest grossing of all time. However, after its release, I have seen many mixed reviews regarding the cultural sensitivity of the film. After watching it myself, I noticed many positives and negatives of indigenous culture in your film. One thing I do admire about this film is recognizing that people overthrowing the indigenous land, life, and world is bad and that these things are wrong. I think recognizing that in today's day and age is very important and it is good to see that on the big screen. However along with that I notice the flip side that many people see that you pick and choose what you want to use to make your story. Many, including myself, see some of these things as very in-genuine and feel that when you pick and choose, you do so for economic benefit rather than maintaining the dignity of indigenous people and their culture. Without allowing these people to have a major say in what is being portrayed, you will continue to drive harmful views of these people to everyone around the world.

Dear James Cameron,
I am a cinema arts student from the University of Hawaii tasked with analyzing your Avatar films. While discussing the first movie in class I came across a controversy on how you chose to portray native people and their culture as well as their behaviors. The issues presented are that there is not enough credit given to a specific indigenous culture that you used inspiration from but by my thinking I quite like the way you've laid out the imagery of both Avatar movies. Avatar one presents the visual representation of a white culture exploring the native culture and experiencing what it means to open the way you thought more with the feeling of invasion by the native people. 
Exploring Avatar the way of water was more a native invasion of native, showing the difference in cultures and not just mashing together the idea that all indigenous people are under one umbrella. The different Avatar people have different actions and different beliefs that account for where they are located while also having the same base built on the way we act as people toward nature. It is true that your portrayal of the different cultures could have done with a bit more creative direction from inside one specific culture instead of adding many to one area for a place that is said not to have ventured away or have experienced outsiders before. The use of more indigenous actors could easily make this concept flow easier while still allowing for the merge of behaviors.

Dear Mr. Cameron,

I am writing to you about how much Avatar has inspired me as a filmmaker. I can never forget the night my mom says she got me and her boyfriend at the time tickets to the showing of Avatar when it first came out. I remember sitting in the first row with my big old 3D glasses in a theater full of people, getting blown away by the gorgeous scenery of Pandora. I could almost feel the wing blowing on my face when Jack and Natiri glided through the air. I want to touch every interesting plant when the night falls and see the neon glow they have. I also want to have my own Avatar body and live in the giant home tree and maybe tame my first banshee. Here we are at the end of 2022, watching The Way of Water. Again, you brought me back to my 10-year-old self, filled with hope with excitement. Thank you for giving a 10-year-old boy the journey of a lifetime and the dream to become a filmmaker. 

Sincerely,
Yixiao

Regarding your second Avatar film, I have a list of pros and cons that I think your movie showcased. To begin with the pros, I appreciate that you took the effort to hire a linguistics professor to create your own language for your fictional tribe. I believe if you had chosen to use an already existing language you would have faced even more backlash from the native community. I also believe your breakthroughs with CGI are incredible. While the storyline of the second film may not have been as strong as the first, I can recognize your advances in technology. Some critics I must include your casting. It was honestly quite shocking to me to find out that the voice actors of Jake Sully's sons were white. Especially considering the heavy accents they both had. I also believe you could have hired more skilled voice actors for the children considering none of them had the same accent despite growing up together in the same tribe. It was very disappointing to me that you could not take the initiative to hire native people as your voice actors, especially due to the sheer amount of their culture you incorporated into your film. Another issue I had with your development process was the fact you barely had any native consultants on this film. As I am sure you are aware, you are a white man with no experience of native culture whatsoever. And yet you decided to take customs from many different cultures and mix them together and play it off as though it's fictional to make yourself sound better. Not only did you take these customs for your film, but you also portrayed them wrongly which is quite embarrassing for you. I believe someone with as many resources as yourself should be able to find consultants to ensure you were at least portraying these cultures in a correct manner. But I do give you credit for the storyline. It is a great concept for a film; however, I wish there were other people on your team that could have ensured this movie will be great. Disregarding the cultural aspect, the first movie was by far better. I noticed a lot in the second film that you touched on subjects that were very important but then never discussed them again. For instance, Kiri has a seizure underwater and almost dies because she asked her mom's spirit who her dad was. That was a major scene in the movie and yet the audience was made to forget about it later. I understand you will be touching on these topics later in the sequels, but it almost made no sense to bring them up now. Especially since your entire trailer began with Kiri talking about how she can hear and feel her mom's heartbeat. And yet for this film specifically that had no strong importance. It was misleading, and I believe that's why a lot of people were confused or disappointed with the actual storyline. Another issue I have with Kiri's character is the fact you reused Grace's voice actor. It made Kiri's character feel much less authentic because an old woman's voice was coming out of a child's body. It just made no sense, and it made me not enjoy the character. Was it really that difficult to find a teenage girl to fill the role? The voice actor did not even try to sound younger. Overall, the film was not bad but there were some major aspects that made me walk out of the theater feeling unsatisfied. And I believe that is why this film has rated much lower than the previous one.

James Cameron's "Avatar: the Way of Water" is an ambitious, thoughtful and suspenseful science-fiction blockbuster suggesting that filmmaking is an indispensable tool for raising awareness about global warming. With sequel, Cameron employs sci-fi spectacle to shed light on importance of building a modern-day universe that is sustainable. It's the filmmaker's first attempt to honor ecosystems in a genre world-famous for escapism rather than environmental activism, but he pulls it off successfully. Using spellbinding cinematography, Cameron immerses viewers into the world of Pandora where the ecosystem is valued rather than looked upon with stigma as in America. Evoking James Cameron's "Titanic", Cameron effectively uses the ocean to showcase the shipwreck repercussions of environmental destruction. Recalling Jack & Rose's maiden voyage journey on Titanic ships doomed to sinking tragedy, Jake Sully must learn to survive on oceans to save family. If "Avatar" took place entirely upon the confined planet of Pandora showcasing its lush rainforests, the sequel captures devastation done to the world's oceans. Cameron shows immense control over production-design, editing and music, crafting an unforgettable cinematic experience. Cameron's screenplay is also sensational, using subtle water symbolism to celebrate the world's ecosystem. One appreciates astonishing performances. Sam Worthington delivers one of his greatest career performances as Jake Sully. It isn't simple to communicate emotions underneath motion-capture makeup, but Sam succeeds tremendously. With riveting expression, he conveys bravery, determination and regrets of a protective father that strives to protect his family from environmental catastrophe. Although facial expressions of the supporting actors are hidden beneath mo-cap makeup, they excel at portraying their characters. From a technical standpoint, the film shows how far visual effects have progressed since 2009 with jaw-dropping motion-capture performances which are on par with Andy Serkis' "Planet of the Apes" trilogy. Although "The Way of Water" is a superb sequel, ultimately it can't quite capture the sense of wonder of its superior predecessor. At three hours, it suffers from a lengthy running time that tests viewers' patience. Moreover, it builds to a conventional ending that appears intended solely to setup future sequels. Nevertheless, fans of the sci-fi genre will definitely appreciate "Avatar: The Way of Water" and so will movie-goers seeking enjoyable entertainment. If Cinema is an art-form with the power to change attitudes towards the environment in America during the modern era, hopefully revisiting the fantastical world of Pandora in the sci-fi genre will encourage the general public to recognize the undeniable existence of climate change in a country torn apart by environmental stigma where the destinies of natural ecosystems all-too-often lie in the hands of greedy politicians elected based upon their charisma rather than talents that are driven by a political agenda.

So I've watched Avatar in the theater (that stank of mice), and I found it offensive not only to my olfactory senses but to my intellect as well. The plot of The Way Of Water is so watery I am not even going to apologize for the overly obvious nature of my pun.

This story, it's so silly, I don't even... Well, sea (ha-ha) for yourselves: so the "Earth baddies" return to Pandora to get Sully for treason. Sure, they let slip somewhere that they also want to do some colonizing and terraforming, but seeing that in all the 14 hours of screen time they did exactly none of that, the whole colonization thing must be just a side quest to them. Somehow Sully realizes that all the hubbub is about him personally, so he says to his wife and kids "Hey, I got a great idea, since these angry earth dudes are after me, our presence here in this village is endangering the other other villagers, so let's all up and leave, and run and hide, and this way we shall PROTECT the village!"

And guess what, his suddenly spineless wife, instead of shaming her sweetheart Toruk-Makto into calling the banners on all the tribes that he'd supposedly "unified", after a moment's hesitation she says "Sure, that's a splendid idea, I fully endorse it, let's do it at once." And they pack up out of there and leave their kindred behind for the earth baddies to stomp (because, remember - they are still colonizing the heck out of Pandora no matter what). The Sacred Tree, the ancestors' graves, their relatives who are about to get massacred: everything is abandoned -- we're running, babe! He was the Chief of the tribe, too, mind. 

"When danger reared its ugly head
He bravely tucked his tail and fled
Brave, brave, brave 
Sir Toruk-Makto!"

So they go and instead of settling on some distant uninhabited island where no one can find them, they join another village, so they can endanger THEM with their presence instead, which is what ultimately happens. Of course, duh!

After about a week-and-a-half of screen time of us watching them bond with the locals (who happen to speak Sully's tribe's language, how convenient, eh) and frolic in the waves and do synchronized swimming with sea-turtles and whales, the bad humans naturally catch up with Sully in his new tribe and turn everyone's life to sh*t.  But instead of feeling an e-e-e-tsy bit annoyed with Sully's family for bringing the war with them, the water tribe is like "Yay, what joy! You are now our BRETHREN! In fact, we are so pleased with you, why don't you stay with us forever? Here's our underwater Sacred Tree, go pigtail-copulate with it to complete the ritual!" 

AND THEY DO. 

THE END.

Yes, that is the story.

I guess unpopular opinion but, I didn't like the movie very much. Visuals are great and fights scenes are pretty good but everything else just kinda fell flat. Story had a lot of plot holes and some of the smart characters make incredibly stupid decisions. SPOLIERS
One plot hole was the whale hunting or whatever they are called. How were the able to hunt there for so long and not be a target for Jake or the other tribes. Why would the smart magical daughter take the toddler with them knowing they would most likely run into a fight for them to get hurt or captured. Another thing is the writing. It's just so bland and made me cringe so God damn much. When this gets released everything they say bro or cuz I'll take a drink and be hospitalized a quarter way through the movie. On to the villains. In the first movie it was a battle for Jake to choose between saving the humans or the Na'Vi. This made the humans the villains that you could still understand and relate too. This time the humans have made Na'Vi clones of the first evil humans and instead of having them be relatable in anyway (unless you relate to manhunting for the sake of manhunting) they are just evil. Also why did Jake and his wife run from them when they had maybe 7-10 Na'Vi soldiers max and the 2 of them took out all of them, half in the first encounter. They already couldn't be found and they were winning this Gorilla war so there was absolutely no reason for Jake to take his family and run. Anyway just a meh movie that is way too long with meh writing, meh plot, and breathtaking visuals.

Avatar the Way of Water is a movie that brings you back to Pandora. The beauty and the time James Cameron took for the first movie, showing the world of wonders, can not be matched in its sequel.

Even there are some moments where you see its beauty shine through the thick heavy fighting scenes, they do not amaze as in its predecessor.
The movie is a blend of a try-it-all, the dialogues feel forced, the storyline is thin, the acting not flawless, and above all misses the heart and soul of the characters.  Was James Sully a hero in the first, in the sequel he feels overshadowed by his younger son. Cliché's on cliché's pass the revenue. For example the sea girl and the son of sully who is struck by lightning when seeing her, falling in love immediatly, but as Sully would say fittingly about this "Sully's stick together"… Where have I heard that sentence before…

With more than three hours you you feel moments you just wish the movie was going to bring something spectaculair and daring. For a brief moment there is the beautiful friendship of Tuljun Payakan (the sort of whale). This should have been a focus point of the movie. The developing friendship within him and Sully's son is beautiful.
But after this the movie just goes all directions and (spoiler alert), when the eldest son dies, you feel not the grief or sadness you should (as with the ancient tree that was knocked down). Sigourney Weaver lays all movie in a casket, even she is voicing the daughter who is a teenager and sounds like an older female. Tuk the youngest daughter is just annoying and shouldn't have made the final draft of the script at all.

All but all, the movie is okey to watch if you don't care about stories, arcs, character backgrounds or development, nor their emotions, and you like fighting and action, this movie is for you to watch.

But sadly the movie doesn't reach the highlights as in the first, and that's a pity. Especially thinking how much the costs were. With many Avatar movies to come, I wonder where it all will go and how much Pandora can take before it becomes like the Disney prequels and sequels nobody even remembers.

I actually held off watching this movie until last night for one simple reason:  the original Avatar was so good, in my opinion, that I didn't see any way for Cameron to create anything that captured the awe and magic of the first movie.  I mean, the original was so groundbreaking.  It was so immersive, beautiful, and engaging in practically every way.  It's hard to find movies with so much CGI in it where you completely suspend your disbelief and are wholly invested in the story as it plays out.  Plus, we all remember the Jurassic Park sequels: they had a really hard time feeling fresh and different from the initial movie that made us stare in wonder at a world with dinosaurs.  I feared the same fate for this sequel, and I didn't want the first movie ruined for me.

But Avatar: The Way of Water blew all of my expectations out of the water!  It builds upon the existing world of Avatar and none of it feels stale!  It still feels like "Avatar"...but MORE.  I loved it!

I worried about the introduction of children into the story (I don't think that's a spoiler because the previews show it) because it can be hard to get invested in CGI characters because we're kinda hard-wired to relate to other humans.  In the original movie, we were introduced to Sully as a human, so we related to him a little easier, I think.  For me, I found myself having a hard time getting emotionally invested in the CGI children.  There's one human "child" (he's a young adult and not really a "child", but...) and I found myself aligning more closely to him instead of Jake's kids.  But I didn't necessarily mind that too much and it wasn't a big distraction...and I DID end up investing somewhat in those characters, but it definitely took a little time.  It didn't help that the kids all looked the same.

But don't let that deter you from watching this movie!  I was expecting some degree of disappointment and went to the theater expecting to pick it apart and find something wrong with it.  In retrospect, I should've just enjoyed it the ride...and you should too!

This movie should attract a lot of people to at least try scuba diving, and experiencing a completely new world, right here on earth. I wholeheartedly recommend it..

James Cameron makes a triumphant return with the long-awaited sequel to the 2009 box office hit, Avatar. The biggest problem this film faced was the significant time jump between release dates, however, Cameron managed to maneuver around this, creating a captivating story that left plenty of room for further developments. Unlike the first film, this one focused heavily on emotions and familial relationships. It created the bond that so many of us long for when it comes to friends and family, and it made the events of the film a little more harrowing as they established very quickly that nobody is safe. Much like the first film, this one continued the storyline of environmentalism and colonization, effectively putting the audience in a place that has them rooting on the side of the Na'vi – and against their own people. 

In order to tell this story in the manner that was intended, Cameron waited until he had the technology available to create an immersive world for his audience. Especially with the use of IMAX and 3D effects, the viewer can feel transported to Pandora for the full length of the film, and will grow to miss this universe when the credits roll and the screen fades to black. The CGI for this film was masterful in every way and it can be difficult to find a cast that possesses the talent to perform with the technology that will assist in building this world. That being said, casting director, Margery Simkin, could not have done a better job. While the entire cast provided wonderful performances, Zoe Saldana (Neytiri) stood out with her emotional performance as not only a warrior, but a mother and wife as well. It was refreshing to see that, although she has different priorities now, she still held on to her values and beliefs in the same manner as the first film. 

The only thing that I felt this film lacked was a memorable soundtrack, as it seemed to blend in to the background of the film and was not as noticeable to me. However, this is not always a bad thing. It was still an important aspect in creating the desired atmosphere, and it did not overshadow the incredible action sequences that appeared throughout the entire film. 

With perfect pacing on a three-hour story that left me wanting more, it comes as no surprise that this film is quickly approaching the coveted $2 billion box office mark that very few films have seen – one of those being its predecessor, and another being Titanic (1997), all with the same director. Whether you are a fan of the franchise, director, actors, or just mildly interested in the story, I recommend seeing this film in theaters as it is a heartwarming and thought-provoking experience that is sure to make you excited for the third film.

I might be wrong but for me it felt obvious that this movie is primarily made to shake awake people to see bad human behaviour that should change. It touches several fields like war, nature, medicine and kindness in general. Through many scenes I was feeling sadness like a torture but at the same time was thinking „yes, please show it to the people, please let some more feel/understand and maybe think of changing something in their way of seeing the world and acting in it". I never saw a movie that did this so effectively and with such uncompromisingness. Not to have a deep story but something that feels a little bit pointless seems to be part of this concept to transport those thoughts like the amazing visual effects do. Its obvious that more parts are to come and I am interested to see what else those movies will show the world. - Maybe do not plan to much for the rest of the day after seeing the movie as you might be in a thoughtful state.

Get a intermission,, or some thing. 3d was fantastic, and bright,, so they improved it a lot. Before you had to sit at the center, now it can be seen at any angle. D minus for not being able to tell a beautiful movie in 90 minutes.  Bohemian Rhapsody was 5 minutes and  55 seconds,, but that's a song you don't have to stare at it. D minus for unnecessary length of movie.

I absolutely enjoyed the movie, and I didn't mind that it was 3 hours long. I gave it 4 stars because Kati being different and her powers were never explained. She is actually very special and gifted but it wasn't fully shown what she could do until almost the end of the movie. Also, I understand ending on a cliffhanger, because there will be a 3rd movie, but there were too many loose ends.
Stunning!! Would definitely recommend 3D and on the big screen.

The story was just okay for me. Maybe on the better side of okay. I could have done without the main character and villain. It just felt like they were forced into a beautiful world that they don't fit in but perhaps that the point? Their characters were just too reminiscent of a completely different genre. But thats just me. 

They made it clear that there will be a third film so I cant wholly fault the plot holes BUT this movie was 10+ years in the making and it deserved to feel like a completed work! I think sacrificing a film even in the slightest for the sake of what could possibly come next its a huge disservice the the saga as a whole. Don't ask such big questions without delivering slightest bit of an answer.

Though overall, I really liked this sequel. Visually, the film was  spectacular, stunning, amazing, all of the complimentary words. So much so that I didn't feel the movie's length or slower pacing all. Zoe Saldana‘s performance was also stellar.

I have not suffered though a movie this much since Wyatt Earp.  Fights are drawn out so long and with so much repetition, that even the characters chime in on this absurd fact,  saying thing like" I can not believe I am tied up again". Yes indeed,  neither can we. We also can not believe, that the villain form the last movie has to be killed again. Avatar1 , in addition to being visually overwhelming for the time it was made in, had charming characters, and a very captivating story. Avatar 2 does not even manage to get you interested in a single Character. The only person whom I found even remotely likeable, was a Biologist, who shortly appears aboard a sort of whale hunting vessel. He has nothing o do with the rest of the story at all.  Surprisingly the CGI has remained exactly the same, even though 14 years have past. The main Characters have gotten an entire litter of children neither of whom gets any character development. You do not actually get to know them and  they all look alike anyway. The only name of a child that I can even remember is Kitty, simply because it was such a ridiculous name for a blue alien child. Instead of focusing on the interesting nature of the alien Planet or, for that matter, a story,  this movie focuses on endless repetitive fighting scenes and the annoying and rather boring revenge lust of the villain form avatar1. The main character  Sully treats his own kids like a shitty patriarch overlord, constantly blaming them for something, while repeating the same line, that protecting his family gives a father purpose. We jump back and forth in-between petty juvenile pranks, endless fighting scenes and yoga like breathing exercises. We are supposed to feel for the absurd amount of nameless kids, because occasionally they feel like they do not completely fit in. Oh my. One time kitty seems to have special powers with sea animals, but she never really uses them for anything interesting. The entire row behind me was asleep by the end of the second hour.  I rate this the second most boring movie I have ever seen.
The exact same movie as the first one except it was in water. Film sound cut out at the end.  Theater's fault.

I don’t know if that’s a good or bad thing but if you were someone who watched as the first time and did not like it, watch it again, and don’t be so judge mental because everything you disliked about it the first time, he won’t even remember or even pointed out. My only bad take away was how the dialogue could've been so much more meaningful. They had the scenes played out perfectly, high tension situations and extremely high risks. But the dialogue ruins some of these scenes. Once you notice this it takes you out of the movie immediately. For example, if a certain character is doing an action others don't agree with. You'd want them to have a real debate and try to convince on another. But no, most of these scenes result in "don't do it" "you can't do this" "it's not right" they missed out on so many impactful learning lessons and depth on what a character truly wants.

Like I have blinders on. Seeing a huge IMAX screen feels more immersive to me.. but I'm getting off track.

To me this really felt like a redo of the first movie. I did appreciate the extra work they put in the further develop the relationships and to give the kids some personality. But the story still felt pretty flat, predicable, and tired to me. A mostly re-telling of the story from the first movie. I had hoped for more on the story and script side. I was disappointed there.

The actors all seemed to do a good job and they were compelling. I think Zoe Saldana really was better than most of the other actors she was working with.

Overall I was disappointed and had expected more from the story and the experience on a personal level. From what I read about all the work they did on the script.. I had hoped it would have done more with it. The reasons that all the fighting was going on.. just didn't seem motivated or make much sense. The movie just wanted action and fighting it seems. Oh well.

I have a rule when I go to a movie. Never leave before the popcorn is gone. Good thing. Or I would have left much sooner. But if you want to entertained by a story, and enjoy the characters, this ain’t the show. It is full of plot holes, has unexplained story lines, and most of all, is just plain boring. After one hour and 45 minutes, with an hour and a half to go, I asked myself: “Should I stick it out or go home and watch something on TV with my wife.” I chose the latter. TV was way better than this colossus of a disappointment.

The beginning of the movie focuses on building the new characters, connecting the old characters to the new, and then moves into the climax that focusing on taking us into the NEW world of Pandora! The plot could of focused closer to home with more emphasis on certain key points to connect the story better. Over all though these graphics were out of this world! Literally diving you head first into the Way of Water! My expressions would of been interesting to record as my imagination literally went wild discovering these new creatures, water plants, sea animals and so much more! The new characters were interesting I particularly liked the character Kiri but for some reason I didn't connect with her facial features in comparison to Neytiri who is obviously every woman's favorite character! Spider played a good character as well but I wanted to hear more from him. He didn't speak much through out the movie. The new water characters were beautiful and creative! After I leave this review I will head down a rabbit hole to learn all of the new character names and who played each one! The whale creature and the connection with the younger son was amazing! I really love the fact that they are relaying a message to the world"let's take care of Mother Nature". I sincerely think as we progress into 2023 that the entire planet will take a step back and appreciate God's Creation just a little bit more after Cameron's brilliance blows our minds once again 💕🙏!! Over all very well done! The emotions the movie brought to the table and the visual effects will have me catching this film in Dolby, IMAX 3D, then repeat! Superb job as always James Cameron!

Lets hope someone at Disney gets this note.
SOUND IS HALF OF THE MOVIE!!!
When you get lazy with sound effects to an audience that watches movies, they notice the Jurassic Park, Tom and Jerry, or generic horror movie growls RIGHT AWAY. You can put a billion dollars in their eyes, but they hear Dollar Store in their ears.

If you need monster roars, go to a zoo, record animals, slow it down, down pitch it, layer it with other animals, reverse it if need be, and get your fattest intern to clean his sinuses over a tin bucket to get the BEAST FROM PLANET X or THE GORGON OF THE 7TH ABYSS or EXPERIMENT IIX FROM LABORATORY XII.

Same goes for music. Take an extra 2 months before release for post so that an orchestra can COMPOSE to the edit of the film you decided on. GET RID of all the temp tracks you can (Because everything has sounded like Hans Zimmer for the last 25 years it feels like). Maybe try some Beethoven, Mozart, Orf, Rachmaninov, or other composers for inspiration? YEAH, you are mostly making action movies, but your big BUM DUM BUM DUM timpanni and French Horn can STILL sound badass with violins and trumpets.
Always trying for a Christopher Nolan Tuba Fart for trailers or a Spiderman style faster little heartbeat sound for action scenes IS DULL. AND IF NO ONE IS COMPLAINING, THAT IS BECAUSE THEY DON'T KNOW BETTER AFTER 25 years!!!

Listen to the soundtrack to Conan the Barbarian, A Lion in Winter, or Lawrence of Arabia. Take it in! You can have ninjas from space over that stuff, if you must be modern and thrilling. Heck, imagine Darth Vader with the theme for Lion in Winter behind him in a scene. The audience will flip out with joy at that OOOMF in the sound without even changing the tempo.

I took my 11 year old to see part II. She cried and so did I. What a beautiful continuation of the Avatar series. The under water features were great (we watched in 3D) and the color so vibrant, of course. The storyline was easy to follow, but not too complex for the younger ones. Although the movie was a bit long, we didn’t have a problem sitting and enjoyed every minute of it. Use the restroom and load up on snacks. If you liked the first film, I don’t think you’ll be disappointed!

As usual, Cameron is all too eager for spectacle and expensive effects to take precedent over any amount of narrative cohesion. After nearly a decade of production time, you would think that the story to go along with these flashy visuals would be beyond something a second-grader might conjure up during a classroom free-write, but you'd be wrong. The stunning pictures and animation can't hope to keep my attention for the 3 hours of the directionless and stilted narrative to painfully play itself out.

It was in the new RealD 3D - 4DX.  The  RealD - 3D was really cool and added to the amazing cinematography of the movie. The 4DX immersive multi-sensory cinematic experience was way to distracting. I would not recommend for a 3 hour action movie, if at all. It lost most of the thrill before the opening trailers were done.  The novelty was totally gone by the first 30 minutes. The seats shook so much that our drinks went flat. It was really funny to see people who bought big buckets of popcorn.  Trying to keep it from flying out of the bucket. 4DX tickets were twice as much as the normal price and it was not a great experience.

This was a good movie. Saw it in 3E IMax.  Not a lot of 3D parts. I didn't like it as much as I liked the first Avatar for a few reasons.  The dialogue was poor. They used slang and American language in the Avatar culture. They also used American cultural norms in a totally different culture. An example was the way the son was disciplined for not listening to his father and how the father ran his family like an army. The cursing was pretty culturally off as well.  The fighting went on way too long. I got very bored with it. Could have taken 1/2 hr or more off the movie.  
The underwater scenes were wonderful. Could have been more of that. 
I still liked the movie but if there is a sequel will have to be done much better to keep me coming back.

It's no surprise to some that I am not as big of a fan of the first Avatar as a lot of people, but given that the sequel has gotten a lot of praise and it took 13 years for us to get this follow-up, I decided to finally see what all the fuss was about. Needless to say, I believe the praise is warranted. Avatar: The Way of Water is a beautifully shot, directed, and yes even written film. The movie has stunning visuals that will leave you breathless especially if you see it on the largest screen and in 3D. The movie also has beautiful performances from its entire cast with the character of Kiri in my opinion being the real heart of the movie. The film even has very touching moments with even one scene truthfully leaving me a little choked up. If you are still on the fence of seeing the film, I strongly suggest you check it out while it's still and it's theatrical run. You will not regret sitting through this 3-hour epic!

The mantra :
"The way of water has no beginning and no end. The sea is around you and in you. The sea is your home, before your birth and after your death. Our hearts beat in the womb of the world. Our breath burns in the shadows of the deep. The sea gives and the sea takes. Water connects all things. Life to death. Darkness to light. "
refers to the Bruce Lee's quote:
""Be like water making its way through cracks. Do not be assertive, but adjust to the object, and you shall find a way round or through it. If nothing within you stays rigid, outward things will disclose themselves.

Empty your mind, be formless. Shapeless, like water. If you put water into a cup, it becomes the cup. You put water into a bottle and it becomes the bottle. You put it in a teapot it becomes the teapot. Now, water can flow or it can crash. Be water my friend."
"

Truly superior movie-making with stunning visuals and an even greater element of family than in the first film.  The 3D isn't much more advanced than before, but that's not a negative.  It’s immersive and still the best.  Some have said the story is thin, but I disagree.  This is the story of the Sully family at this moment, this period of time, and it's certainly enough for anyone who would be going through it!  No lags, no drags, and many scenes of beauty.  Predictable, as some say?  Not in any way you don't want it to be.  There are certain cadences of story we all love and usually expect.  It hits those notes while providing a lot of originality.

A side note: In the climactic events, there are several touches that reminded me a lot of images from TITANTIC, which you'll likely notice if you see this.

James Cameron has proven once again that sci-fi/fantasy is where he shines as a director. Avatar 2, like the first Avatar, is an enthralling, engaging tale of "final stands" and "let's end this"s. The magnificent animation is best represented by the colorful seascapes and truly incredible (fictional) marine life depicted in the film. Unfortunately, one pretty large issue with the movie is the rapid introduction of random pieces of information and the leaving open of enormous plot holes (intended to set the stage for the next movies). From the survival of all of the villains to the question of Kiri's father's identity, so much was left so completely up in the air that viewers were left unsatisfied with the conclusion. Additionally, the introduction of certain pieces of information ring of deus ex machinas, which have no place in sci-fi cinema. But, again, the special effects definitely make up for the lack of solid plot structure. The entire viewing experience was spectacular and I'd rate this movie highly.

Anyways I think you should treat yourself to experiencing this movie in the highest quality theater you can find. Definitely not a movie to watch at home even with a great home theater setup.

Avatar: the way of water
This sequel continues in the same traditions as the first movie. It's a visually stunning piece of art with a message that's not properly explored.

With otherworldly visuals, Avatar 2 takes audiences into never explored lands in Pandora. The runtime of the movie is long, not unbearably long though as the visual treat is mesmerising enough to ground a viewer; it's ironic that with the lengthy runtime, avatar 2 still feels rushed. 

The story is thin and the dialogue is poor (the constant use of 'Bro' from the young actors was cringe worthy, and gives off a poor image of what old people think young people sound like); Avatar 2 is heavily centred on family, but even this isn't portrayed properly. Various subplots are raised and tossed carelessly, while the main plot is also rushed through just to get to the big finish. The characters aren't well fleshed or developed properly; some characters are borderline unnecessary.

The action scenes are grand and well choreographed, and the final act is heavily influenced by Titanic (a movie also made by James Cameron).

In all, Avatar 2 is a visual spectacle with a relatively thin plot that lacks poignancy.

As I entered the cinema to watch this movie I must admit I had my doubts, 13 years since Avatar had released, I was worried that this movie would have issues bringing me back into the world of Pandora, however I can safely say that the movie had succeeded. 

The movie begins in the same time period as the last one, and it feels like reuniting with old friends, Jake Sully, Neytiri, the good RDA scientists (I forget their names), but we are shown a montage of the years as they pass, which I believe is about 13 years, so you feel as though the world has caught up with you the viewer, and the Sully family has grown, they have children, but their lives are surrounded by a constant war against the RDA, ever intent on poaching more resources and land from their planet. However Jake makes the decision to flee the region, and go into hiding with his family, to the tropical region of Pandora, where a new type of Na'vi reside.

The characters are all their own, Jake and Neytiri are more mature, having raised a family, but their children are the highlight, in fact a majority of the story surrounds them, and their struggles fitting into a new society of Na'vi, however what's great is how Jakes children all have their unique personalities, one is more headstrong, one is more gentle and timid, but then you have his youngest daughter, Tuk, who never failed to make the theatre laugh during her comedic moments.

Visually this movie is breathtaking, the last movie having released in 2009 was stunning to say the least, but this movie elevates the visuals by bringing forth such a distinct sense of colour and vibrancy. The introduction of a new region to Pandora, a more seaside, tropical ocean landscape, surrounded by islands, rocky landscapes, and a sweeping ocean to boot, there is so much eye candy that your visuals may develop cavities. Cameron has made an effort to flesh out the world of Pandora by introducing a new species of Na'vi, an aquatic type that mainly relies on the ocean and it's species to travel. I love how these Na'vi are different, they possess bigger hands, that are more akin to fins, their culture is slightly different to their Omatikaya clan, and from what's been said about the third instalment by Cameron, I'm glad more is being done to flesh out the world even more, it really makes it all the more believable as a fictional world.

The score was composed by Simon Franglen for this instalment, as he replaced James Horner who as we all know tragically lost his life in 2015. However, Franglen nailed it, the music is soaring, it gives this sense of weightlessness, yet it also envelops you with a feeling of wonder, a desire to view the unknown, funnily enough, how the ocean is. There is also a track done by The Weeknd, which plays at the credits (I particularly loved his song for Black Panther, and I'm quite a fan of his music so I may be a little biased here but it is a fantastic track)

There are some aspects of the story I feel left me feeling a little underwhelmed sadly, some storylines were left unresolved, and I felt that for a movie that runs for just over 3 hours, there was little seen of some characters such as Neytiri and Kiri (Funny story, but for the entire movie I thought her name was Kitty, and apparently a lot of people thought the same, until I saw it's actually Kiri, so that happened). Nevertheless, I believe the reason why some questions have been left unanswered is simply because it will most likely come up in the next instalment. So, all that's left to do is wait for that, and hope we don't have to wait another 13 years!

So the simple question is this, would I recommend this movie? Yes I would. It's enjoyable, its visually appealing, and there's a good blend of action scenes with more mellow, intimate scenes that overall combine to provide an enjoyable watch that'll certainly entertain.

Avatar: The Way of Water perfectly embodies the phrase "style over substance". While the visual effects will have you in awe and the script invests a lot of time into expanding the internal lore of Pandora and the Na'vi, the characters that inhabit that world are not particularly interesting. James Cameron makes an effort to develop his protagonists, he is so preoccupied with worldbuilding, that the heroes are overshadowed by the scenery. We get a love story, that does not really go anywhere. Jake's adopted daughter, Kiri who possesses special powers tries to learn more about her past, but her quest proves fruitless. We don't even get a partial answer as to why she is different. I guess that will be explained in the sequel....  The action scenes are of plenty, but none of them will hold you in suspense. The sense of danger is practically non-existent as, despite the state of the art tech at their disposal, the human villains are no match for the Na'vi warriors and are easily ambushed by them. Once again, Cameron uses heartless, incompetent military types, who brutalise the innocent and use and torture to achieve their goals as the antagonists of his picture. I am tired of seeing these kind of characters being used as an excuse for evil in films.

I went into this with high expectations, having loved the first movie. This second installment was in love with its own narrative, and not in a good way. Too long, poorly paced, lacking originality or unique content… Very much a "white savior" narrative. So much of how this family dynamic is built makes no sense from the lore and dynamics of the first film. Neytiri has lost all agency and is just a set dressing for Sully and the kids. It falls to the same flaws of recent Star Wars films- we're expected to care about characters we have spent no time learning about.

This film is the definition of "meh." This film is just so BORING. There are stretches of this movie where literally NOTHING happens. I get the whole argument of "You're supposed to immerse yourself into the world.", the the world itself is really boring. The setting for most of this movie is this stupid ocean region of Pandora that isn't really interesting. The setting makes this film impossible for me to truely immerse myself into what is happening. All of the characters they add are nothing characters that do nothing. This entire film is just one big hollow mess. I will give this film credit because the visuals are as stellar as ever, the team that animated this film deserves a raise, they're phenomenal. Other than the phenomenal visuals, this film is very lackluster. Go see Puss & Boots 2 instead.

I came into this movie with fairly low expectations and I had seen many people complaining about it being "boring" and "having no meaning". It is three hours but I did not at one point find it boring as it is not super slow pace. The thing that really makes this film stand out is the animation visuals. even if it's not your kind of movie, it is worth seeing it in the cinema for the cinematic visuals. It's true that it has not got much of a meaning or character development but I think this is an unfair criticism as it's a CGI alien movie, it was never meant to have vast character development or a deeper meaning. Avatar is an action film and it's not trying or should try to have deep themes and meanings. I don´t think it is in any way an amazing film but it looks great and is great to watch in the cinema, especially in 3D. One thing to bare in mind is that you should watch the first film before.

Now it's considered one of the top 5 films ever made. Reviewers here give better descriptions than I ever could. The one thing you should know is one of the best directors ever spent 12 years making this movie and you can see it in every frame. There are no dull spots in the three hours and 12 minutes. We know some of these actors ( Kate Winslett ) trained and spent as long as 7 minutes shooting under water without taking a breath. I couldn't tell when the actors were in real water or GC water. If you want to be transported to another world. You have to see this movie.

Long, but what a ride through a wild world of bioluminescent plants and animals and a LOT of strategically-placed loincloths. The CGI will blow your mind and you'll think the Na'vi are actual beings alongside the human actors here. The technical, mechanical and biological designs on display here are some of the best future-tech and alien-worldbuilding we've seen yet. The running time might be daunting and if you're not into sci-fantasy you'll probably fall asleep like one fellow in our theater... but if you like special effects, and film-making technology, and spectacle you should enjoy the heck out of this.

Sincerely I found the CGI to be the most compelling aspect of the film. All scenes featuring a number of different visuals were combined in perfect balance and included moments with shots undistinguishable from practical application. 
Nevertheless, and regardless I found the plot and the storyline to be predictable. It seemed as if the template of the first movie was copy-pasted. In addition, the story hasn't been made extensive enough to answer the questions which the audience had been posed with. For example; we never find out why Kiri had unique abilities which connected her to Eywa. To mention additionally, the plot of the story has showed a scene with the mother; not revealing the identity of the father; leaving many questions about Kiri‘s origin story unanswered. Considering the scale of the project I think it would satisfy many fans to receive a rounded up story and prevent possible plot holes.

An absolutely enchanting experience, very much like the first Avatar. Like the first, I love this one with my heart and soul. There was laughing, there was crying, there was sheer happiness from finally (after 13 years) being able to experience this amazing sequel.

The visual was obviously good, but the story is too weak and predictable, there are too many characters so some of them seem useless to the story, the only characters who are well-developed and compelling to me are Lo'ak and Kiri, most of the good moments in the movie involve them. 
Maybe it's just me, but honestly, in some places I didn't understand logically why what is happening happening. Also, it repeats the 1st movie too much.

But my main complaint is that in the beginning the movie gives you very high stakes, but then it forgets all about it and in the end the stakes are only the main characters' lives, and those promised high stakes are left for the next movie. So that's disappointing.

Visually stunning and beautiful.  But the story is dog excrement.  Once again, Jake Sully is an outsider that finds himself in a strange new world he has to acclimate to.  Instead of learning to ride flying dinosaurs, he has to learn to ride swimming ones.  Instead of unobtainium, it's whale goop.  Both have a magic tree, but this one is underwater.  Oh, and the dead villain from the last movie has been saved on disk and downloaded into an avatar body--along with his entire squad--with the sole mission of hunting and killing Sully--because having to create a WHOLE NEW villain would've been too much work apparently.  Nevermind that the Avatar bodies are so absurdly expensive that its the reason they used Jake Sully to begin with.  They can apparently just develop them willy-nilly now.  Remember, Cameron ONLY had 13 years to work on this.  Not only is the villain resurrected, but turns out he had a SON--Feral Justin Bieber--but he's actually sided with the Smurf people.  Like the first, it's worth a once over in the theater for the visuals, but it's got very little rewatch value.

James Cameron invites us to see and revere the vividness and the wonder of life all around us and the vividness and wonder that biological life and living to the fullest could be. For that alone, it deserves five stars. Then, there is the reverence it gives to community connectedness and family ties. For that, it earns it again. Those two well-earned values far outweigh the predictability of the plot. Plot spoiler: once you understand the premise, pretty much the way you thing this plot go, it will go that way. But drop that. Forget that and just enjoy the moment because what it does have to offer is many golden moments that will enrich your life and boost your spirit for months to come, maybe for a lifetime. Lose yourself in every well-told moment and you will come away a happier, more respectful, more hopeful person.

I really wish they had more character development for the human characters vs just 'Human bad, Na'vi Good' 

The movie didn't completely lack it, but there just wasn't enough. 

Don't get me wrong, everyone loves a clear good vs evil story. But what I want to see is one where the moral areas are gray.

It could be that with Avatar, sure the humans are invading Na'vi land, BUT they're also doing it because their planet is DYING, and they're trying to survive. 

Again, doesn't excuse the treatment of the Na'vi. But I would love to see more exploration of Character depth rather than just 'tree good, human bad'

The effects and visuals were outstanding as expected, but the story...UGH! So many, what I'll generously call, parallels to the first movie. Plot holes galore. The biggest one you have to ignore as the main "story" gets going is: Why did the main characters think the villains would stop hurting the rest the Na'vi tribe if they left??? Did they send a letter to the bad guy saying "Hey! Quit killing our people because we're not there anymore. We left to go far away and they have not idea where we are anymore." Later in the movie, when the bad guys showed up looking for the Sully clan, they didn't take "We don't know where they are" as an answer, but they'd accept and walk away from the people they lived with for over a decade?

BTW, why were the avatars for the bad guys grown, or stored, all the way back on Earth? It seemed like the avatars in the first movie were grown, or at the very least, stored in the main base on Pandora? Made no sense, but on that point I could've been wrong.

Even if you ignore that, the rest of the story seemed like a rehash of most of the first movie but with water instead of trees, and instead of a tribe resembling Native Americans, it's a tribe based on Pacific Islanders (yet the queen is voiced by Kate Winslet...the whitest of white people. HA!!!). I heard a rumor that one of the sequels will take place in desert type lands. Can't wait to meet the Na'vi with the Middle Eastern accents and culture since Cameron can't make up any original aliens. There were no surprises. You could see pretty much every turn, plot point and event coming a mile away. Except the talking whales. That caught me off guard when it turned out they understood sign language and communicated in a way that the water people and Scully clan could understand. Also, who tattoos whales?

In then end, it was 3+ hours of pretty pictures as long as you shut off your brain when it came to the story itself...not unlike the first movie and I bet the sequels will be the same. Still, I love the visuals and will probably still give Disney and Cameron my money to see them on the big screen too.

Avatar movies are like rides. They are more like the attractions at Disney World or Universal Studios than they are like the movies you watch on Netflix. When viewed in 3D IMAX these movies are incredible, physically immersive experiences. And that is by design.

Sure you COULD watch Avatar on your tiny screen at home, just like you could watch a video of a roller coaster at home. But why would you do that? Roller coasters were not designed to be fun if you watch a video of them, you have to actually RIDE the dang thing to see what the fuss is about. Avatar is the same way, you have to see it in 3D IMAX if you want to understand what people like about it. That's how it is is designed.

Yes, I was skeptical.
And yes, it was, much like the first one, an outstanding immersive experience. You are transported to another world and all of the work and planning is up there on the screen. New landscapes, delightful creatures, and a new group of characters are introduced to provide us with more opportunities for awe.
We had the opportunity to watch this on the IMAX in 3-D, and it was well worth the effort.
Once again, I was bothered by some of the really incongruous language and slang. "Bring back a scalp" is said by one of the antagonists as well as "Let's go buttercup, get up" followed by "I'm not your buttercup, perv!" There are quite a few more of these slang terms from our current time that just seem jarring and wrong in the 2160s (the time period of this sequel). I don't think people would actually be saying these phrases in a time when travel to other planets is possible.
On that note, I was taken aback by the number of new and shiny weapons of war/pillaging were introduced and it made me ponder the following: how could the people of a planet that was dying have the resources to create such amazing tech, and not be able to save the planet. But then, I've answered my own question. That's EXACTLY how it will be when we get to that point. It's our nature.
Like the original, the "sky people" (short of a few scientists) are driven by greed. A sign of things to come, I'm afraid. And we won't have a Pandora.

Humans comeback to terraform pandora because the earth is dying... ok but you come on the planet with ships with gigantic nuclear reactor that completely nuked tge ecosystem of the planet? Makes sense indeed. So many plot points make no sense or are pourely written that it kept me from being fully invested. 

There's a human character here that keep switching sides here and there. It could have been a good plot point but it isn't. The father-son relationship here should have been a bigger focus.

Talking about father-son, the son of the main character Jake Sully is such a 2000's teenager. The amount of "yeaaah brooo" "daaamn dude" he says during the film just sounds so weird. Wasn't he raised by a soldier? Is there internet with an access to earth's socialmedia plateforms on Pandora?? Maybe the writters wanted to appeal to a younger audience, but it doesn't make anysense here.

You really end up hating the living hell of the humans in this film. Wich is both a good and a bad thing in my opinion. I think Cameron focused to much on the humans with bad intentions here and didn't have enought good humans. The 1st movie had this duality in mentality and it was definitely a strong part of the movie.

In the past few years, I've seen a lot of large budget, CGI heavy, plot weak, strangely long run-time, Marvel films.  Avatar has a lot of similarities with those films, but ultimately I liked it quite a bit more.  

The plot structure is pretty conventional and the movie drags at certain points, but pretty much everything else is very well executed.  While I was able to identify that I was watching a fairly stock scene (e.g., the "hero at their lowest point gathers their courage and fights back" scene), those scenes did what they were suppose to effectively.  I was sad when a blue cat person died and I felt triumphant when an alien whale thing got revenge.  There were setups and payoffs and brief, efficient visual metaphors. Avatar demonstrated that James Cameron has strong directing fundamentals, even when directing a film that was probably 99.9% CGI.

The CGI itself was truly top of the line, and the movie is probably worth watching for the CGI alone.  I don't think I've seen any other film handle water visuals so effectively.

While James Cameron created a visual masterpiece and does a great job telling the story, it's not a story that's particularly compelling. The story is a little too illogical to really make sense. For example, in the first avatar, humans were hell bent on acquiring the metal unobtanium. Early in this movie, they tell us it's really about taking over the planet and making it the new earth. But instead of concentrating on taking over the planet, they decide they need to kill one of the characters from the previous movie. Killing him has no effect on whether or not humans take over the plant or not but all resources from the humans and military efforts are focused on killing this guy. It's nonsensical. Then we discover later on that it's really about harvesting a substance from one of the sea creatures. A substance that stops aging. But again, that has nothing to do with the humans hunting down and killing the one guy they are after. It's just a big mess.

I usually don’t leave reviews for movies but this one was different. 13 yrs later from the original film James Cameron has done it once again, but better. What they have done with visual effects is the best i’ve ever seen. You forgot that the Na’vi people aren’t real because he has made the world pandora so real. The water, creatures and the landscape are some of the best i”ve seen in a created place. The story to me is a much better one than the first film. Focusing heavily on family and Jake trying to do what he has to do as a father and keep his family safe. His kids for me stole the show. Tuktirey was the cutest. Kiri was a misunderstood teeenager who had a greater calling to Eywa. Neteyam was a fierce warrior and great older brother. Always trying to look out for his younger brother Lo’Ak. Who is the star of the movie to me, who brings it home towards the end as to why he’s the character going into the future as the main character. Overall i loved the movie and it’s one of the greatest experiences i’ve ever had with a film.

Avatar is still Avatar. Nothing new and nothing worse to call it bad, is somewhere in the middle. The new movie is an expansion of the Pandora universe and shows how would these people live in water. Its visual effect is just as good as the first one. This means that more than 10 years later James Cameron has successfully delivered the same effect to the screen and didn't offer us anything new, while we watch similar technology become commonplace amongst other movies and game titles. This movie would be much appreciated if it came out much sooner after the first one. This is not to say that it is a bad movie, but I don't think it was worthy to watch when it should have been delivered a long time ago, and especially when it takes around 3 hours to finish.

My first thought in reviewing this: It's fine. 
The visual effects are absolutely stunning, but the plot is seriously lacking. I've never actually seen the first Avatar, (Being partial to District 9, which I think is a much better 2009 alien movie) I thought that it showed what happened in the first movie without actually explaining it in a great way. The problem is, in almost three-and-a-half hours, it seems to accomplish next to nothing. There's romance, friendship, intrigue, and family building, but it's shallow and seemingly random, as if James Cameron wanted to show off his CGI skills and throw in random plotlines in between, half of which are completely abandoned. For example, Kiri's connection to Pandora itself, like, what happened there?! She summoned some glowing stuff! I'd compare this to Arya Stark in GOT, where she spends so much time developing her powers only to use them once. Another thing is the older brother. (Neteyam or whatever his name is, see? I can't remember it!) He gets NO plotline and just dies for the fun of it! If he had an actual personality we would have cared! It also has no LGBTQ+ representation, like this is 2023, we should have this in mainstream movies already. I think that Avatar: The Way of Water is a visually stunning movie, but needs work on the plot.

Dialogue and soundtrack more about explosions, gunfire etc than dialogue, and very little explanation about the new characters, unless you can remember the storyline of the first Avatar 13 years ago! I certainly will not be watching the 3rd version unless it tones down the violence and has a little more substance.

James Cameron's sequel to Avatar (2009) in which the Na'vi Jake Sully, chief of the Omaticaya clan, who lives with Ney'tiri and their newfound family formed on the extrasolar moon Pandora, must seek refuge with the Metkayina clan under renewed human threat. After such a long production, which involved new technology in order to film performance capture scenes underwater, a feat never accomplished before, this movie was meant for greatness after the astonishing success of the first movie. Watching it in IMAX 3D as it is meant to be seen, was a magnificent out-of-this-world experience and definitely immersive. However, the plot is a bit simple and the decision to keep the same villain could be seen as tedious and not willing to take risks with a new villain in the third film could lead to disaster. The Tulkun parts of the movie are extremely sweet and tragic and these creatures are the highlight of the movie. But this is one of the prime examples of a fantasy world done right, with its extra-realistic visual effects and its complete lore. I would have liked a more innovative score, but I guess no one can surpass the late James Horner.

People who think this is a good movie are the same people who like music by Imagine Dragons and think that salt is a hot spice. Pretty discouraging that a lot of people fell for this. It feels even dumber that JC is already working on multiple unwanted sequels and an Avatar universe lmfao.

Avatar The Way of Water is basically the same as the first installment but with more characters that unfortunately aren't fleshed out well enough for you to care for them. The storyline of this second version of Avatar was basically almost exactly the same as the first movie 13 years ago. It even seemed that it didn't know which direction it wanted to go and just mashed up different events and ideas randomly together into a 3 hour movie, which eventually left you with an unsatisfying feeling. The 3D effect is however yet again top notch, you feel as if the characters were real and alive on screen, however I am afraid that the 3D gimmick has worn out over time, that 3D alone wont contribute significantly enough anymore to make a film watchable.

So the revolution is not happening. At least that's how it seems based on the script (especially the scenes with the developers who choose to mine whale extract instead of ore) and the romance between Lo'ak and Tsireya, which tried to remind or imitate the relationship of Jake and Neytiri with the already hackneyed I See You ... where during which there was zero chemistry between them (since Lo'ak has a relationship with the whale rather than her). More interesting were the characters of Kiri and Spider, whose story component is a little more interesting (since their origin is shrouded in mystery), but unfortunately pushed to the background, because frolicking in the water and fighting the enemy (which, in my opinion, is completely easy) is more important as a story arc (the only ones who more or less have this story arc complete are Jake and Neytiri, who are less important here than it seems). In short, Avatar 2: The Way Of Water delivers a nice visual (for which it gets 10/10 from me)
    but the script is only weak 4/10 (Cameron dealt with nostalgia and references to his previous and other films (Titanic Free Willy and Avatar) while it harmed the idea of ​​the film and the more complex portrayal of the characters that the film would have moved to a better level (if the script didn't rip off other movies and focus more on the characters then it could be as good or even better than Avatar (2009) but I'm sorry to say that the first Avatar was better because it kept something in me that only the second sequel can hardly repeat...

No story spoilers yet. Only general opinions. 
The movie was a bit campy at first, but fun if I tried not to take it too seriously. Entertaining beyond the slightly silly parts that I don't think were intended to be silly. But by the end of the movie I felt generally unsatisfied - it made me sad without an enjoyable adventure along the way. I'm not even sure if I'm glad I saw it or not. It was also more violent than the first installment. 

Spoiler time! You've been warned. 
There was VERY LITTLE EXTERNAL PLOT DEVELOPMENT from the beginning of the movie to the end. The third movie will begin much the same as this one did: "The general is after us, but we just want peace." Externally, the movie begins and ends almost identically. Everyone was in the same position they were in at the beginning of the movie, but having lost someone along the way. I had the feeling that the whole awful fight, and a significant character's death, had been pointless. They objectively lost the fight. Nothing was gained, only lost. It wasn't worth it. There's no resolution. Infuriating.

As for internal character conflict and change, it was enjoyable and satisfying in certain capacities, but there were still so many questions left unanswered that I felt frustrated when the credits rolled. I felt that several of the characters moved on from their shocking and uncharacteristic behavior without recognizing its weight or making real change. I am not confident that any resolution of some of these plot points is yet forthcoming. So, I am left to disapprove of several of the main characters and still be expected to root for them. I eventually felt very disconnected because of that. 

This is not in line with James Cameron's usual high quality. For an original story, which is rare these days, I am grateful. The visuals were almost unmatched. It was an enjoyable ride. But from a writing and plot perspective, from a storytelling artistry perspective, it was very disappointing. Part of me wishes I had never seen it.

The CGI in The Way Of Water looks like a video game, a good video game but still. The 3D is in and out of focus in some scenes and is generally a blur when there is a lot of action on screen.
There is no real plot and there is no set up to bring new viewers up to date from the first instalment. 
Acting is as good as you could expect from not using real actors. Computers can only do so much to bring the characters into a believable world setting.
All in all, I think this movie is one you could wait for home streaming on. There isn't enough content or good effects to warrant the $70 that two of us with snacks paid to see this. 
Maybe James Cameron could have watched the first Avatar to see how well it was put together and how much more effective the CGI was to get a better feel for how to make a sequel. No real characters, mediocre special effects and no plot are OK for video game but not for the high budget block buster that this is supposed to be.

Visually, the movie is stunning, and like the original, the underlying message is obvious, but still poignant, and this Avatar has left me waiting for the next chapter to be released so I can continue the adventure with the clan.

Avatar, Way of Water was very disappointing, to say the least. I was a huge fan of the first Avatar movie, but Cameron lost me on this one. The militaristic emphasis was not only very apparent, but also can be seen as a deliberate attempt to railroad the Light work being achieved on this Earth. I left the theatre with a very bad feeling, due to the unnecessary use of violence in the movie. Cameron even had the audacity to bring violence into the Light - filled scenes, by making the characters portray extreme violence as they defended against the Sky People. The end of the movie was of course, the best part as obvious Lighted magic came forth through the daughter to save the family. To me, that was the highlight of the movie !   Cameron has said that he will make more of these Avatar movies, but he will not be getting my money !

An astounding movie. The visuals and certain concepts of the movie, like the hyper-environmental theme were fantastic, and dare I say mind-blowing. However the action scenes and the ultimate ending needed some editing. After the third or fourth cliff hanger and the length of the film, I was getting exhausted.

Love the cinematography but so tired of endless violence on the screen - artsy or not. Children will watch this film and the amount of shooting and negative action (ok, balanced with some good values about protecting family) is way, way too much. Film makers need to rethink endless violence. Good writing doesn't need violent scene after violent scene. We are desensitizing youth. Avatar is non-stop war. Enough! James Cameron is talented enough to write better themes that reflect values that uplift humanity. Films enter the populist psyche - what do you want people to learn? How do you want society to be? Lost count on how many bullets were in this film. Disappointing.

Although, the period of when the main plot is ignored in favour of character development for Jake's and Natiri's children, it is very much high quality and a great watch. 

There are a couple of not so very likeable characters (also new) and replayed tropes from the first film which can be a little distracting, but once again the execution of the film in whole outweighs the negative and easily ranks as one of the best films of 2022, and the last decade. Outside of some too-artificial-looking CGI, the entire visual experience was truly stunning and inspiring.  The storyline was trite at best.  It was all too predictable.  Take the avatars away and really, this could be hundreds of other "I'm-coming-to-get-you-and-take-your-kids-hostage-while-I'm-at-it" action movies.  On top of all that, it was about 30 minutes too long.  I'm fearful that there was probably about 50 hours of footage that wasn't able to be stuffed into one film and all of that will rear its ugly head down the road.  So visual impact gets 5 stars.  The rest of the movie gets 1 star.
