Much like the first 'Avatar,' 'Avatar: The Way of Water' is a feast for the senses. The movie is, of course, drop dead gorgeous, featuring the absolute best visual F/X ever put on screen, but I was surprised at how emotional the film is. It has got to be one of James Cameron's most personal films, despite the expansive fantasy setting. The importance of family is a strong theme carried all throughout the film, and you can tell Cameron was drawing from his own experience as a father.

It's hard to deny the impact these two movies have had--and are having--on people. You can quibble about the story being too thin, or the kids getting into trouble too often, or a variety of nitpicks, but you'd be missing the point.

The movie also gets bonus points from me from not featuring a "go here, get this, do that" MacGuffin storyline. What a breath of fresh air.

It's very rare that I walk out of a movie before it's over. I made it all the way through "Larry The Cable Guy: Health Inspector", so I naturally  assumed that I could make it through anything. Well, that was until today, when I was unfortunate enough to attempt to watch AVATAR: THE WAY OF WATER! It is SO uninteresting & utterly boring, in EVERY possible way, I just absolutely HAD to get out! The two people I was watching it with, clearly felt exactly the same. We were all looking forward to this movie too! Anyway for me personally AVATAR: THE WAY OF WATER ties with HALLOWEEN ENDS as the 2 worst films of 2022. It's devastating to write those words, I assure you...

IMAX 3D was simply amazing. The cinema experiece is why I give it 5 stars, as for story it had some issues and inconsistencies, but it didn't take away from the experience. It deserves the accolades it's receiving. James Cameron is a top tier director and I even got teary eyed watching it a few times. My daughter's jaw was open the whole time and had a blast watching it. I look forward to all the future installments, there simply is no other cinematic experience that made me feel as though I was watching something truly special and ground breaking. Avatar makes the movie going endeavor and the price of admission worthwhile! Kudosa to all the VFX and animation artists behind all of the visuals. They don't get enough credit for what they do. They are the true magicians and innovators of our time!

Some say its a forgettable story and that "you probably cant remember a single quote from the movie" (which is a funny thing to say because the Avatar movies have been very dialogue-sparse by design. You remember the story through its scenery, visuals and the actions that where taken, not through the dialogue spoken.)
While yes the story can be seen as forgetable if you're focusing purely on words spoken, what makes it (at least to me) UNforgettable was the visuals of the movie that have engrained themselves into my mind.

I'm not a huge Avatar fan. It's not a movie that I get hyped for but, I saw this one and for 3 hours, it didn't feel like it, at times.
There were some slow areas but the final act of the movie flew by.

However, I will say this, the CGI was amazing. It never felt clunky or out of place at any point like some Movies.

The world of Avatar is a truly enchanted and inspirational place. Imagine living in a world where every creature you meet is a contributing and respected member of your community. Then imagine that every member of that community had an equal amount of respect for every other member. It's a vivid and perfect utopia that I have never before and can, even now, barely imagine. 

Now imagine that every few years, James Cameron sends Intergalactic Colonial Marines to shoot your animal friends in the face and then burn your homes and churches to the ground in the name of a plot device. 

I don't think I'm going to see any more Avatar films.

This movie is an absolute must-see! the setting, plot, and everything were very well thought out. the duration of the movie is 3hrs. and it was well worth it, wish it was a bit longer...lol! I'm patiently waiting for a part 3, I know it'll be coming. As long as the same MAIN characters are in it, I think it'll be successful.

Not as good or groundbreaking as the first.  Did not have the intriguing story and plot of how humans adapted to avatars or became avatars.  This was a hard sequel to make.  Overall, it was great, but just an impossible task to live up to the first movie.  Hopefully the sequels get back to where the first movie was.  This movie also felt long while the first movie you didn't want to end.
Outstanding special effects. Let's hope it doesn't take twelve years to make the next.

The special effects and visuals were entertaining but the plot line was thin.  It did not need 3 hours!
Also, people who did not remember the first Avatar movie were confused about what was going on in this movie. The ecological message of the movie about the value of holding animal life precious was strong.

I honestly really loved the movie.  When I watched the first one; I was really young and it was with my grandparents at the time, but I loved the first one so much… and every year we'd talk about our hopes for a second one lol… typical ig… but I'm happy the 2nd came out now…. I'd say it's kinda slow in the beginning and sort of middle because of the actual showcasing of the beauty of the water tribe and the surroundings.  It really shows all the hard work that was put into the making of this film.  It was so surreal and beautiful… etc…. It's so hard to put words into how fascinated and surprised with how the movie turned out.  I honestly didn't think it could get much better in visuals, but I was oh so wrong.  I mean the storyline was kind of average, but I honestly still vibed with it lol.  I just like the references and stuff with how the world is now and our treatment towards the planet.  Seeing these visuals in the film… is something I've never seen in real life before… nothing as pretty in nature.  I've seen some beautiful things but nothing that wasn't necessarily touched by humans… 

To sum it up… since I probably was too passionate about this lol…. I thought it was amazing and awe-dropping.  

I totally recommend it for those who really appreciate the beauty and hard work these people put into the film.

A worthy successor to the original. In this instalment, the forest world of Pandora is replaced by the ocean environs and - like the predecessor all those years ago - I was wowed over again. More than simply stunning effects, the ocean environment of Pandora is believable - being both familiar and entirely alien by taking our (Earth) experiences and visualisations then projecting them through the lens of Pandora. It is as much a voyage of discovery for the viewer as it is for the Scully's. At the heart of (good) science fiction are core human values - love, family, fatherhood, identity, loyalty, friendship - and while the CGI and effects are spectacular, the heart of the movie lies in the story. I walked away from the movie uplifted ... just as I had done after I saw the first Avatar.

Avatar: The Way of Water moves the series forward in beautiful, cinematic fashion. While the stylized action and visuals may carry most of the film, an emotional tale of family still resides in its center, serving audiences a heartfelt, if long story.

Pros: Obviously, the CGI is absolutely stunning.
Performances all around are good, beautiful production design that's lifted higher by strong cinematography. Cameron continues to dominate as a director with this sequel, as well as the score. On a technical level, it's a marvel.

Mixed: pacing feels perfectly fine in the film, but aspects of it could have easily been cut down. The story has enough key differences, but it still resembles the original film's plot a little too closely.

Cons: Screenplay, while not terrible, does have some weaker moments, especially near the beginning.

I was disappointed that they reused many of the elements of the thanator attack from the first one, and instead of unobtainium funding their mission they invented a new miracle substance but still brought all their mining equipment along for the ride. 

There is a point where we are interacting with Eywa, and I thought it would be used more but instead it turned into something probably saved for the next sequel. 

All in all I felt it was a very good movie, though it wasn't as groundbreakingly awesome like it's predecessor. I still thoroughly enjoyed it and can't wait for video release to watch it with my dad (he is hard of hearing and needs subtitles).

Great art is a lie used to tell the truth. Avatar is sci-fi of the highest order. A fantastical world used to hold a mirror up to humanity—our system of capitalism and our disconnection from reality. If you loved Avatar 1, you'll probably like Avatar 2. Maybe I was expecting way too much, but HEY! I have been waiting 13 years for this! If Coppola could deliver Godfather 2 two years after No. 1 and Lucas release Empire Strikes Back 3 years after New Hope, I think we should expect awesomeness, right? Technically speaking Avatar 2 is breathtaking. The level of detail and physical simulation is totally beyond any other feature film. I just wish that Cameron would have worked on the script with as much rigor and attention to detail. Do we really need to repeat another teach them our way of life sequence? Aren't there any other bad guys in the universe besides Colonel Quaritch? Did they sell out of themes at the theme store? Why do humans always have to exploit natural resources for money? We do a lot of other really bad stuff too which could create great conflict for our blue heroes.

If I'm still alive when Avatar 3 comes out, I will probably still go to see it. I'm invested now and still hopeful that Cameron or his descendent will deliver something spectacular. But I'm the kind of guy who would stay up late to see a lunar eclipse or passing comet because they are rare and I still seek wonder.

Wow. I don't know when the world decided to turn on Avatar but the first one was one of the first movies I remember transforming my imagination. I was 9 when it came out and it invited me into a world I had never even thought of. And now I hope everyone has learned to never underestimate James Cameron. Avatar: The Way of Water is the most visually stunning movie of the year that manages to tell a fantastic, albeit very long, story of family and respect for the world around us. The world building is insane, two movies have fleshed out Pandora so much already, granted that's like 6 hours of content at this point. I love the added bioluminescence that is all over the place in this movie. Now yes, this movie is long as hell but it's paced so well that it almost seems to fly by. I was tempted to look at my watch once but then got sucked into the movie and never thought about it again. Sam Worthington still does a great job as Jake, and it's nice to see him changed now that he's a father. Zoe Saldana is such a gift, she is truly amazing as Neytiri, but she does get done a little dirty with a severe lack of screen time in the 2nd act. Sigourney Weaver does a good job making herself sound like a teenage version of herself. Stephen Lang becomes a much better villain this time around with more depth. Kate Winslet, Cliff Curtis, Joel David Moore, CCH Pounder, Edie Falco, Brendan Cowell, Jemaine Clement, Jamie Flatters, Britain Dalton, Trinity Bliss, Jack Champion, Bailey Bass, Filip Geljo, Duane Evans Jr, Giovanni Ribisi, and Dileep Rao make up a great supporting cast of new characters and brief returning faces. Honestly there are a lot of characters and I hope I got everyone because the blue faces make it a little hard to recognize some of these great actors. The score from Simon Franglen is the perfect cherry on top of this movie. It truly is just so beautiful and deserves the praise it's getting. IMAX is a MUST, the 3D is good but not necessary. I am most definitely giving Avatar: The Way of Water a big 10/10 and a bigger recommendation. I am just so excited to see the rest of this franchise now, I never left the ship but I welcome back all those who left. -Tyler.

Even though it was long, the story was so engrossing, the time went by quickly. The effects were dazzling. I was a little disappointed at the blatant open ending. Guess well be seeing a third installment. Im looking forward to it!

Cinematography wise this movie is a masterpiece. The visuals are amazing and next level with James Cameron (the director) making many sequences 48 fps in order to get a crisper image for the sequences. However, where the movie falls short is the story. There were many scenes where someone would say something important and it would never be mentioned again even though that important thing seems crucial to the story. I also feel like the movie was way too long and that many of those scenes I referred to could have been deleted. I also felt like many of the characters did not get to work together. Even though they all had their moment to shine. Others just got tossed aside while others worked together at the end of the film. Now I know I’m being picky and that most of these issues will be resolved in a later film, but I feel like these issues could have been fixed if James Cameron deleted one scene and added onto another scene that did not get enough time to progress and evolve in the story. While this movie does have its issues in story telling it does make it up by having amazing visuals making this movie a visual masterpiece and a must see in theaters.

Same plot, more or less, as the original. I found the bad guys in this film to be right out of the cloak wearing silent movie villain mould, over the top evil characters with barely no redeeming character traits.
Having murdered a navi that spider had been almost a brother to for his entire life, this particular evil doer was nevertheless saved from death by spider simply because he had the memory implant of spiders father, which apparently trumps killing your boyhood friend and generally destroying and murdering your way across the planet. All of this to push the Cameron narrative that family comes before all, even if by family you mean a 22nd century, or whenever, usb stick.
As for the dialogue, the use of the word bro, or cuz became so jarring both in its frequency and awful, unnatural placement, that it started to annoy me to the point that I started thinking about who passed this trite script, rather than being immersed in the action.
It killed 3 hours +, so that's a positive in rainy winter time Britain, but I'll never watch this again

As expected, technically speaking, this movie is a  wonder. Narratively, however, it's far from good. The 3 hour run time was excusable in the original as it had the incredible task of smushing an entirely new alien world into a single film, but Way Of Water relies on cliché after cliché to pass the time, with some scenes making me chuckle out loud at their absurdity. Unfortunately, not even the new backdrops introduced are enough to give this movie a pass, as all of the flora and fauna felt like a simple reskinning of the ones we had already seen in the original. Overall, I was disappointed in this film and I can't really recommend it unless you're just so into cgi that you can't miss it.

Avatar 2 is visually incredible as anyone can attest and I loved experiencing it in 3D. The children and camerawork both work together to create an extraordinary viewing experience. It's also a quality action movie, certainly better than nearly everything from MCU phase 4. I had fun watching it. I think the return of colonel quaritch and his team was done pretty well. I also think adding a family dynamic to the story helped a lot with the repetitiveness of plot points. "Bro" was used way too many times throughout the movie. Speaking of the siblings, Tuk was flat and served to only as someone to be rescued, this will hopefully change in thr next movie. And Neteyam, the eldest, also felt flat which served to create an emotionless death scene. Lo'ak and Kiri are definitely the best developed if the four but are so much so that they outshine their siblings. Sigourney Weaver plays a teenager with ease.  I also liked the development of Spider. Jake's whole arc this film was basic to say the least but well-written and I would say pretty in-character for him. But I love how the very reason Jake had his family leave (his need to protect his children) is the same reason they were found . While I may be a family man I also love good film and especially good science fiction. To put it bluntly this film is a terrible sequel and absolutely abysmal sci-fi film. This film is mind-numbingly stupid, while the original wasn't smart film-making by any standard it at least knew how borrow tropes well and used them to decent effect. It also knew how to handle its science fiction concepts properly with its world and how we understand things. This film not only managed to make the humans more cartoonishly evil, but stupider, less imposing, and less nuanced. This was the film to do the opposite here. This was the film not to waste people's time with pacifistic, migrating, telepath whales who don't actually have telepathy. This was the film to expand your science fiction concepts not break your previous rules and only add one more in a throw away line in which we see absolutely zero results. 

As such I give it 2.5 stars as it easily could have been a fantastic film by just tweaking its ideas and making people smarter, unfortunately it's so dumb that it almost makes the original Avatar worse by this one's very existence. Ultimately the first Avatar is better.

He is out and next second he is in. Sometimes it seems edits were in the wrong order. The sudden acceptance by the villain of his son , just like ship, doesn't hold water. The flagrant stealing of Māori culture to me was a bit crass. A missed opportunity to share about the planet and ecology turns into a violent pissing context between sully and the family and the colonel. Cheap and easy just like the edits. The film could have been an hour shorter and we would have missed nothing. Unfortunately we will be exposed to a third one no doubt. An emotionally charged movie that could have and should have been more than the cheap and easy gore fest it is. Very disappointed. Oh yeah the 3D was a distraction too. If I ever meet mister Cameron I will tell him myself . Dissatisfied disappointed and disillusioned

Visually it is surely the best CGI produced of today and throughout most parts of the movie you will surely find yourself with your jaw dropped in awe. It is like a three hour Nat Geo Epic dipped in with the occasional "historic" fighting, but pumped up with all the Steroids of the whole American Football League. While the Avatars in the first movie often still had a cartoon like appearance, they as all the creatures around them do actually really look alive in this edition. And for 90% of the movie it is absolutely fascinating and captivating, only to be completely screwed up 20 minutes from the end. What script writer and director can screw up a movie so ridiculously horrible after nearly 3 hours of near excellence? Halfway through the final battle the Sully family  is suddenly all alone fighting against each and every of the bad guys left. What happened to the chief of the Metkayinas (sea people), his ferocious wife and all the other dozens of fighters. They suddenly, from one second to the other, simply disappear from the scene, turning an, up to that point, absolutely marvelous movie into a big joke (they all only reappear at the very end on the beach😂😣😤😝). Minutes later after the fighters' disappearance once again, and only to add a few more minutes of ridiculous action, the whole already freed family decides to return to the sinking ship instead of simply swimming underneath the oncoming flames which are obviously only ON TOP OF THE WATER, all of them being able to dive for many minutes at a time. If it weren't for those completely idiotic 20 last minutes the movie would be a perfect 10, but as it is I can only give it an 8/10 points.

Avatar: The Way of Water is a visual spectacle from start to finish. The scenery, cinematography, and CGI constantly had a smile on my face, but is it enough to carry the film?

While the previous entry had its fair share of story-related problems, the sequel corrects most of my issues and delivers a heartfelt family story. The main improvement from the first entry is character development. I had a genuine emotional connection with the Sully family and was invested in their safety. These feelings created some genuine tension when any of the family members were in danger, I felt my body tense up as I waited to see what the conflict's conclusion would be, which is a gigantic improvement from the first film where I could not care less who died or survived.

The return of Stephan Lang as Colonel Miles Quaritch brought the overly campy villain back to the screen in a bad way. Quaritch is a caricature of a "villain" where his actions and attitude are evil for the sake of being the bad guy. His anger toward Jake Sully does seem a little bit more believable hear as his previous self was murdered by him, but the over-the-top theatrics are just too much for me.

Another aspect of the story that did not feel right to me was the children constantly disobeying their parents for the sake of plot progression. Countless times, Jake Sully's kids would do the opposite of what they were told, leaving them in a vulnerable state to be captured. This danger forced Jake Sully to constantly expose himself and help draw the threat ever closer to his family. The moments that result are great as we get to see the dichotomy between Jake being a father and his militaristic background. This is at the heart of the story and worked for me.

I was surprised to see how well-paced the film was despite its over three-hour runtime. There are some pretty slow parts, specifically the second act, but the visuals and the character journeys that happen during these parts are so interesting that they didn't impact me negatively; I was just happy to see new and beautiful aspects of Pandora.

The performances were fantastic throughout. It is a testament to both the actors/actresses and also the technology that can display such complex emotions and visual nuances on entirely CGI creatures. Sigourney Weaver was a highlight with Kiri, who was at the forefront of the entire film. To be completely honest, I did not even know she was played by Weaver; the mix between her performance and voice modulation created a compelling 14-year-old girl that was a huge part of the story. Sam Worthington was incredible and Zoe Saldana was perfect. Saldana does so much acting with her facial expressions as Ney'tirl, which is on display during many emotional scenes her character goes through. She was a bit sidelined during this film, but when she was on screen, she was impactful.

Avatar has some incredibly heavy themes at play. One of the strongest and most relevant messages was anti-poaching. I mention this because there was such a hard scene in this movie that had me on the verge of tears. It was something I'd never seen in the film; it was both beautiful in the brutality it displayed and the emotional response of the Na'vi.

Overall, this movie is deserving of the hype and needs to be seen on the biggest screen available. James Cameron delivered on the 13 years build-up to the sequel and has gotten me excited for the three sequels planned for the next decade.

First time is saw this, I loved it. But I didn't know where to rank it in my top 10 of 2022, so I decided to watch it again and I still loved it even with its faults. The film is visually stunning. James Cameron knew what he was doing because this is really well shot with beautiful imagery and CGI that is so good, you feel like you are actually in the world of Pandora. That leads into the next pro which is how much I love the continued exploration of this world and how immersive it can be. The world building is just as strong as the first with creative creative creature designs and interesting ideas on full display. The score is great but sadly misses that James Horner magic the first film's score had. The acting is good, especially from Stephen Lang who gives a strong performance as the villain. He played the villain in the first film and I found that he was a little generic. In this one though, he is much better explored compared to the first and feels like much more of a threat. I also found there to be some really likeable characters with some of them even being memorable. Surprisingly, the film has a good amount of emotional moments that hit hard, especially with its family storyline. The film is entertaining throughout with the action being just as fun if not more fun than the first, even being better shot than the already amazing action in the first film. That's very prevalent in the very strong last hour where all the action is put center stage with an entertaining, fun, and at times emotional 3rd act. Like previously stated though, it does have its faults. Some side plots I feel don't get enough exploration and feel completely forgotten by the end of it. The films main problem though is how it suffers from some pacing issues and disjointed editing during the 2nd act. Overall though, while the first film is still a great movie, Avatar: The Way of Water improves on some of the problems of the first tremendously and while it does have faults of its own, the good outweighs the bad in this sequel that was definitely worth the 13 year wait.

It was visually stunning but I don't understand how, in the $250 MILLION DOLLAR BUDGET, Cameron couldn't find the budget for a halfway decent script writer? It was lackluster and stale. A budget that large should not allow for anything as bad as this was and the fact that it was visually stunning does not make up for how boring the story was. The character motivations were excessively overused and I was begging for something interesting or original the entire time. My favorite part of the movie was when I left to go to the bathroom. This was not worthy of a three hour movie. MAYBE 90 minutes, but even then, the story was tired to begin with. I should have just watched Puss in Boots. It would have been more entertaining.

There's one scene (you'll know when it arrives) that is genuinely distressing (I don;t mind this in context, but it was easily the least comfortable I've felt in a cinema for some time). The action/ battle sequences are laboured and we still have to swallow that a warrior can fire off a dozen arrows, all hitting their target, none of them anywhere near the main protaginist. 

But I'll forgive all that, if I can just swim with the Tulkans and enjoy the penny dropping about Kiri's origins, something that will no doubt play out in the sequels to come.

As if I needed to hate humans even more, I left feeling like I did. What’s going on on Earth these days where the military is sent to rape and pillage peaceful planets? No laws that prevent its civilian citizens from rocketing to other planets and killing sentient emotional species (or any species) for personal profit? I get the existential parallels to today’s Earth but it dashes all hope that future Earth was able to save its soul. In these ways this movie provides no escapism. The beauty of the Pandora flora and fauna and the Na’vi people can’t be enjoyed for long before the violence and destruction comes crashing in. If there is a third Avatar movie, which I’m sure there will be judging from the gaping opening at the end which really made no sense, then I hope it brings less violence and some comfort that humans aren’t the worst species in the universe (even tho they probably are). Didn’t hate it, didn’t love it.

Avatar: The Way of Water is a spectacular big screen experience. A visual delight that is at times thrilling and wondrous. But much like the first film it is let down by clunky dialgoue and a fairly predictable story. Avatar was a huge film in every sense of the word. A massive box office success, director James Cameron worked many years on making a sequel and I think he mostly succeeds. The film takes place more than a decade after the original. The Na'vi have repelled the human invasion of Pandora and Jake Sully has become one of them and is now chief of the clan with his own family. But their peaceful existence is ruined when the humans return again to colonise Pandora as Earth is dying. Sully leads the resistence so he is a made a target by the humans (or 'Sky People'). Sully and his family escape to live among the Metkayina who live near the water. This is where the film really takes off as the scenes above and below water are quite spectacular. Of course their new peaceful existence doesn't last long and the battle between the Na'vi and the invading humans takes up again. As a visual film this film is quite stunning. There are some sequences that will take your breath away. But like a lot of Cameron films there is little room for character development and the dialogue is quite obvious at times. But this demands to be seen on the big screen. So if you accept the faults it's a fun ride.

When I first heard that Avatar was getting a sequel I worried about the storyline and how it would move forward. While I do like the way they advanced the plot, I found myself bored during many scenes. Scenes that I thought started well and interesting, eventually went on too long and lost my attention. Even the big battle went on way too long. 
Just when I thought it was over, the movie goes into a Titanic sequence and even takes a bit of a turn reminiscent to Star Wars with Luke trying to redeem his father. 
I was happy to see they found a way to bring  back the Colonel who was a great villain in my opinion but the plot line with he and Spider, which started with promise was lacking and fell flat. 
It is a movie that must be seen in a theater to appreciate the effects but honestly I was apprehensive sitting down for a 3 plus hour film and at times many of the prettier sequences were  just plain masturbatory and not necessarily essential to the plot. 
I am not sure I would see this movie more than once the way I did the original.
No discernible plot at all. Way too long. Wasted 4 hours of my life. Loved the humpback whales until they started murdering them.

Astounding movie. A must-watch for everyone.

Yeah, there's nothing and really nothing at all that you will remember from the storyline except for the visual effects. It is an absolutely predictable plot, instantly you will know who is the bad boy and who is the good one, and additionally it is extremely slow from the start and goes on and on and on for three hours.

So for the plot it is hard to find any worse movie. But the special effects are the most advanced and most stunning of all times. And it's not an exaggeration. See it in 3-D and in high frame rate!

Ground breaking cinematography and shots aside. I like the rich world building involved here. The detail in culture differences and tensions that arose from it could have been given more depth by using redemption arcs rather than altruism. I expect to see more development in the love/hate relationships between the two factions and Spider probably getting his own avatar and being drawn away from the Na'Vi to the Merc/Avatars/Demons/Skypeople. I also could have done with less "military" lingo. Being a Marine myself it felt clunky and also irrelevant to the common movie goer. No civilians know what Oscar Mike means and Marines cant regroup in hell, they wont let us in because they're afraid we'll take over. Still a good movie though and I WILL be watching the sequels. James is still the man when it comes to giving the audience a solid fantasy film and visual masterpiece. Thank you James Cameron!!!!!

This was disappointing.  I rewatched the first Avatar when it was rereleased in theaters last year and loved it just as much as when it first came out.  So, I was excited about the second Avatar.  However, it's disappointing in several ways.  The middle section of the three hours, when it really gets into showing the marine environment, is wonderful and beautiful.  But the plot is basically a rehash despite the new setting, and the story is not engaging because of the inexplicable choice by the director to use the kind of high frames-per-second filming technique that produces the so-called "soap opera" visual effect.  In short, this makes it impossible to forget that you are watching people act and pretend to be Avatars.  That aspect alone made it impossible for me to be swept up in the beautiful fantasy world of Pandora, like I was when I saw the first film.  The 3D effect was enjoyable but it still didn't make up for the soap opera visual quality.

После фильма крепко ее обнял. Мое мнение Джеймс Кэмерон из тех режиссеров, которому нужно давать деньги и не мешать работать. К нему прировнял бы Дени Вильнева и Кристофера Нолана. Вот три атланта, на котором держится кинематограф. Уверен "Аватар" соберёт нужную сумму и мы увидим третью часть.

I loved it and seen it twice. If you liked the first one, you'll like this one. I love alien and fantasy worlds, sci-fi concepts, nature (always a sucker for whales too) and weird animals (I particularly love speculative zoology), so this ticks all my personal boxes. Seeing the film in IMAX 3D is like a ride. I would love the story and world anyway, but the visuals definitely enhanced the experience. The story is relatively simple, but that is a good thing - too many films try to cram a series' worth of narrative and characters into a few hours of film and wonder why it falls flat. Films are designed for simpler stories imo. This was also a lot more character driven than the first, which I liked.

Don't go into this film expecting Citizen Kane, just go for some otherworldly escapism and enjoy the ride. It has it's nitpicks in the story (what film doesn't) and is not a perfect film, but it's one of the most enjoyable and solid films to come out in years and one of the only films I'll spend cinema money on as seeing that world come to life on the big screen is a fantastic experience.

The first film was likened to dances with wolves, ferngully etc, but this isn't that story. I'm not sure why people say it's the same story, it's not. It's got the same themes of protecting nature and animals from human brutality, but those are themes. The narrative is much more focused on the kids, specifically three of them who each have an interesting story that will clearly expand in the next films.

¿Valieron la pena los 13 años de espera?
La respuesta a esta interrogante es un rotundo sí. Avatar: El Camino del Agua es una secuela que logra superar con creces a su antecesora. Ya que tiene una historia mejor y mas interesante, así como efectos bastante mejorados. Sin mencionar que expande de muy buena manera lo que nos introdujo la primera parte. Tal parece que James Cameron se planteó el objetivo de asombrar a la audiencia con cada toma, y lo logra. No solo los escenarios son vibrantes y coloridos, sino que por momentos llegan a verse como sitios de verdad y llenos de vida. Y esto no sólo aplica para los escenarios naturales, también los hechos por el hombre tienen su encanto. En síntesis: Avatar " El Camino Del Agua" es una obra maestra de la ciencia ficción moderna.

Visually, amazing. I loved the scenery but the lacking of Eywa's presence takes away from truly connecting with it. I didn't feel the weight of needing to protect the environment they were in
because the threats to it felt recycled and without as much significance as the previous film had.
The amount of characters and their individual plot lines made for reduced empathy for them. Jake had a major transformation last time  removing himself from his militaristic ethos to join the Na'avi and now employs it so heavily it ruins the relationships he has with his kids and puts their lives at risk as they try to live up to him. He is not a complex yet likeable character in this film, rather one dimensional and mean. Kitty's epilepsy felt unnecessary, it was brought up as a major evolvement but then never touched on again - her identity issue is never resolved. Nor was the motivation for hunting animals for their youth juice. They both felt as empty vessels to carry the movie forward without having any weight for themselves.
The appropriation of Pacific Island cultures was distasteful and a rightful reason for Indigenous people to be boycotting this film. With the more than on the nose use of Māori facial expressions and body language, it's hard to miss as offensive.

If you can look past all of this however, the movie makes for an engaging spectacle with you kept in awe of exploring new territories of Pandora.
It was everything it needed to be, and Im only disappointed I have to wait so long for the next one. Perfect visuals, I was entirely engulfed for every moment.

Its a shameless carbon copy of the first movie in virtually every way. It's also gorgeous, which is the real reason we're all here, so it's still very much worth the while to see in theaters.

A few minor elements, like the youngest child existing purely to be a flag the 'bad guys' repeatedly capture, was admittedly infuriating; The youngest child is tied up 4 times, falls off a riding animal several more, and it's so bad that they even have a line where they acknowledge it ("dang it, tied up again!!!").

On the plus side, it's really just a neon nature banquet for the eyes, exactly as we wanted. I'd be just as happy with a Pandora nature documentary. It's still worth seeing because it's just wonderfully gorgeous.

Better storyline than the first, a great expansion of the larger world of Pandora, and more heartfelt than the original.  This is a story about how family changes your priorities and how protecting one's family comes above all else.  The jungle visuals are just as extraordinary as I remember from the first and the water visuals are beyond imagination.  I feel like some critics have been overly harsh on it, due to a fairly mundane and obvious storyline. It's all fine and good to dissect it after watching, but while you are actively watching none of that matters. You are too busy being mesmerized by the visuals and worrying about the true stars of the film… the kids.  Really never a dull moment for a 3 hour behemoth (I was on the edge of my seat from about 30 minutes in all the way to the end) which is also a testament to how good of a film it is.  Overall, a well "worth the wait" sequel, and a must see in theaters.  You are not going to want to be that one person that never saw it on the big screen!

Great movie, if you can get over the fact that our hero had sex with a creature that had a tail. This movie clocks in at 3 hours and 12 minutes.... and for most of that time you forget that our protagonist Jake Sully is a paraplegi,c human living in an avatar aka a Na'vi alien's body, and is sexually involved with an alien. I will give it to him, he is one alien man, not unfaithful, .. but she still is a blue alien with a tail. Let me put it this way. I love my dog, if I could, for a few days, be a dog, I would love that! I would love to take naps all day, frolic in the yard, and, given the chance, take a shit on my neighbor's lawn while he watches me. But if I were a human living in a dog's body, I would not, in a million years, have sex with another dog, not even my dog, who I am emotionally connected to and is a very cute dog. It would be weird... dare I say criminal. But I digress.   
The action in this movie was sooooo good. This chapter of Avatar introduces several young Na'vi characters, mainly Jake Sully's offspring, who were conceived when he had unprotected sex with an alien. The antagonist is the avatar in Na'vi form of Colonial Qearitch. His sole mission is a revenge mission to hunt down and kill Jake Sully's avatar. He is mad at Jake because Jake killed him in the previous movie... side note- if you can believe (and cheer for) a human that has sex with an animal, being able to accept the fact the colonial, died and came back as an Avatar is not a huge reach. I would also like to interject that maybe if you have a paradigm shift where colonial is not after revenge, but rather hunting a man that has sex with aliens, perhaps the colonial wouldn't be considered that bad of a guy... just my two cents. 

This movie also introduces talking whales, who are incredibly bright and have rich dialogue, such as "it is just too emotionally difficult for me to talk about right now" when the whale is pressed as to why he is excluded from the other whales, during their whale games. They were a fun new characters, but  I did get a little uncomfortable any time Jake was around them because I thought he might try and have sex with their blowholes. 

If James Cameron made ET today, I wonder if he would make Elliot a teenager exploring his sexual identity. I would imagine it might go something like this-  "Mom! I found an alien in our shed. We have a huge emotional connection. I think I am going to try and have sex with it."

So disappointed. We were so looking forward to seeing this, but I found the violence off-putting. It was an ode to male aggression, and didn't offer any real redemption for either the avatar planet inhabitants nor humans, becoming more ensconced in making the planet's people look more and more ''like American Indians" defending their lands than a people who could actually transcend such aggressions, as implied by the title, "The Way of Water" (Tao). This is a missed opportunity for James Cameron, who has fallen back on clich good vs. evil, killing with impunity the "bad" invaders instead of teaching better 'ways' to all. Some parts were nice, we enjoyed the children and their character development, the CGIs and artistry of the underwater worlds were phenomenal, but all that did not redeem the film, especially since the children and whale-like creatures were used to wage war when  they could have shown higher evolution and taught better ways or at least been more clever than repeatedly using blunt force. Also, my Japanese friends took offense and felt culturally shamed at the Japanese writing on the whale-killing torpedo's.  Unlike the West, the Japanese did not practice large scale whale commercial hunting until the McCarthy years of the 1950's, when Americans, trying to rebuild Japan and looking to get more protein for the Japanese diet, basically  made them do this? At least they used the whole whale as well. Very few Japanese eat whale anymore, and many are against it.

I hold my expectations a bit on hold before I saw the movie because I couldn't think that this movie could surpass the first one. But it's close. 

I was taken away in a whole other world and after the movie I sadly had to remind myself that I was on Earth and not on Pandora.

Like its predecessor, this is not just a movie, it is an experience!

It is refreshing to see a Hollywood blockbuster focusing on family values and environmental issues without preaching or any identity politics.

Ok, now that that is out of the way, this sequel is a MUST-SEE event, which needs to be experienced on the biggest screen you possibly can see it on. In Imax, I found it difficult to accept the visuals were CGI. The 3D is not gimmicky but aids in the immersiveness of the world of Pandora.

Yes, some will say that the run time is too long, but it is setting up the world of Avatar and the upcoming sequels, lots of exposition, but nothing feels unnecessary or wasted. 

The story picks up immediately from the original, and there are real ramifications for characters' actions. The movie does swerve to a different route once we're in the ocean, but surprisingly and enjoyably so! 

You do get the sense that a LOT was left on the cutting room floor. I do look forward to the extended/bonus scenes when the blu ray is released. 

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!! See it on the biggest screen you can while you can!

I watched this in 3D HFR as intended by the director. I don't like 3D movies as a rule, but I love Avatar in 3D. I thought the detail of how the actors moved, and how facial emotions translated from the mo-cap was impressive. I liked the change in scenery the new water setting brought, I felt the Maori-inspired culture of the new Na'vi tribe was a breath of fresh air, and the added detail of the evolutionary changes between the water and forest people was a nice touch. The HFR really smoothed out the action scenes, but I am glad there was a transition back to the standard frame rate for the slower-paced scenes to avoid the issues that the Hobbit trilogy audiences complained about. The first movie for me was a bit of a romance with Jake falling in love with Neytiri and the forest, but this one really centred around the parents and their love for their family unit. I thought the emotional stakes were much higher because even though there were some corny moments, I found myself getting emotional during some of the sadder moments in the movie, which the first movie didn't really do.

If you want to find flaws in the movie, like with any movie you will find them, but that's an issue not an issme. Avatar 2: The Way of Water is an action, science-fiction movie set in a beautifully unique world with a conservation message at its heart. There are more storylines established making it not seem like it's idling, and any slower moments are used to show the beauty of this rich world. But when the action kicks in, you better hold tight. I would recommend this movie to someone who is an easy-going movie watcher, it's a fun, immersive ride that has real emotional stakes. 

So let's get it done!
Es una digna secuela, hermosa fotografía, grandiosa dirección y efectos, sin desperdicio alguno!

The visuals were stunning , but the story line wasn't so exciting. Between not getting the job done and having to constantly save kids it was unsatisfying. I guess my expectations were higher especially considering it took them 11 years to come out with a " Part Two ".

The movie shows some absolutely stunning VFX. If you enjoy watching impressive displays of CGI and can give a pass on an OK story, I would recommend it. However, if you're expecting a story that is well written with loose ends tied up, perfectly set up for the next movie, and will enrapture you... Eh, this may not be the one. Don't get me wrong, the movie was decent. But SPOILERS:
The bringing back of Quaritch as the main villain felt very lazy and low effort in my opinion. Retconning can be useful in stories. I'm not someone who hates a retcon for simply being a retcon, many sequels and franchises can greatly be improved from retconning small details. However, the retcon of suddenly, the humans had the tech to store someone's entire consciousness onto a little disk and store that onto an Avatar that they suddenly decided to grow for Quaritch just in case so they could bring him back like, a decade later? Yeah, I don't buy that very much. The Sully family also moving away from the Forest to the new Sea home also felt quite forced. I get why from a writing standpoint and it made for some enjoyable scenes and amazing CGI. But I felt like it could've been far better executed.

All in all, the movie was enjoyable and I'd recommend it to most people simply for the amazing Visuals and finally getting the continuation to the first movie. But don't go in expecting a masterpiece of writing and storytelling, just decent.

Then I found myself rooting for the "bad guy humans" firstly they don't have a goal of murdering everything, they just want sully who has been attacking their operations from the start. And the Navi seem too dumb to realize that they could probably negotiate with these humans, and live in "harmony" with them as well. So as a result we watch one of the most visually stunning pointless battles in movie history. And at the end, I just found myself wishing Jake sully just turned himself in and we got to watch the Navi do cool visual things.'' (Nate E.)

Bravo, James Cameron.  You've made a film that surpasses the first in every way.  The story is rich and deeply moving.  There's a realism and looseness to the dialogue which feels fresh.  The family dynamics, as well as those between tribes, are effective and, at times heart-wrenching.  The colors absolutely dazzle.  If you can, see it on the biggest screen possible (preferably Imax, as I did, or in Dolby).  The 3D is awe-inspiring, and at times I wanted to reach out and touch what was on screen.  Whether the focus is on sea or land, life absolutely bursts; however, the scenes under-water are immersive enough to make you hold your breath.  Yes, the film clocks in at over 3 hours but you won't feel it.  You won't care.  I didn't want the visual spectacle to end.  Frankly, I can't wait to visit Avatar for round 3.  This is one of the best films of the year.  On a technical-level, it proves that James Cameron sits at the top of the throne.  Grade:  A+

I'll be upfront and say that I'm a huge avatar stand, so I'm definitely biased, but I think avatar the way of water is amazing. My eyes were glued to the screen as I took in the breath taking world. If you are an individual that doesn't care for amazing visuals and can't stand a semi predictable storytelling, this movie probably ain't for you. If however, you get even the slightest amount of enjoyment from beautiful cinematography, then Avatar the way of water is a must watch for the visual spectacle alone.

I disliked this movie about as much as I loved the first Avatar. I saw the film in 3D and while I was at first wowed by the 3D it soon became a distraction. Also the colors were very muted in comparison to the first film. A vast majority of the film is just tones of blue. 

Now to the worst part of the film which was both the story and the acting. The first film focused on loss, exploration into a fascinating new beautiful world, conflicting alliances and rebirth. This film focused on misbehaving children and the cowardice of the once proud Na'vi race. Neytiri, a great character in the first film, had little time on screen to do anything except scream in anguish a few times. She was channeling my thoughts about how horrible this franchise has degraded.

The whole film was just misbehaving children, blurry distracting 3D, next to no story or character development and 3 1/2 hours I wish I could have back. I would have left early but I didn't realize everyone I went with also hated the film. My Wife, children and I truly disliked this film.

This is what I feared.  It's the same movie as the first one.  I'll mention that at one point the RDP corp says this is to be the new Earth, implying we've exhausted/ruined the old one.  OK, then why just the RDP corp? moving on.  We see the 'star people' return in the sky.  Why don't they take whatever weapons of war they had left from the first one and prevent them from establishing a base?!  oh all that stuff was destroyed to go back to nature.  I thought the Na'vi were smart.  Because the SMART part after the end of Avatar #1 was to figure a way to mine unobtainium eviro-friendly and to work with Earth, not just RDP, to sell it and buy planetary defense systems.  Because any other path will lead to a megacorp invading again and causing death and destruction again. Write THAT movie!

I quite enjoyed this film. The visuals were stunning and the story was intriguing. It introduced enough original ideas to be different from the first film. The length of the movie is something some might be concerned about, but I felt it had a good pace.

Movie was way too long although the 3d viewing makes it doable.  Special effects were truly good (esp shots showing Humans alongside the Na vi) although a few scenes looked like a video game (ground force deployment in beginning).  Much of the time it's like watching a Pixar film but it is an alien world so it's going to look different.  Music was recycled from first movie but fits the theme.  Dialogue/Writing felt "James Cameron" and the plot was woke of course (nature loving natives defending against colonization).  Don't think I will want to see the 3rd one in theater unless he keeps it down to 2 hours.  I miss the days of the 2 hour movie and if you wanted a longer version you bought the Director's cut.
How can you NOT love this?

It did pass the time, 3 plus hours of the same boring plot.  The idea that the same characters get kidnapped, without much creativity really takes away from the effects and colors.  And how about the soundtrack?  Raiders of the Lost Ark it's not even close, the music did not stir emotion.  The characters were too predictable and it missed the emotions of the first movie---so what if a main character dies-let's throw a party and swim some more.  And that whale like creature with its eye---Norwahl from Elf was more interesting-------it had me thinking that Jar Jar Binx was a better character.  The problem with Cameron is that he probably has too many yes men working for him and went all Hollywood instead of hitting the storyline and creating something of emotional substance.  But he'll be BACK.

Visually stunning. Story could have been somewhat better but still was good. Didn't grip me. Ending was... meh, it's just leading up to no.3. "We all just borrow the energy and someday we have to give it back", Avatar the Way of Water was even better on a second viewing. The VFX and sound are incredible, the cinematography and production design insane and the performances emotional. Still can't believe that last hour!
best movie ever best sequel ever

Visually stunning from start to finish. That being said, with a 3 hour run time and a story that could easily have been told in 2-2.5 hours, there are just too many scenes included where James Cameron is doing nothing but flexing his technical movie-making prowess as the expense of telling an engaging story. Was it fun? You bet!! Could it have been shortened and been even more enjoyable? Also a resounding yes!! As is true with many of these big movies, see it in the theater for the immersive effect, but I won't hate you if you wait for the streaming version.
Visuals are amazing , the story had a nice continuation to the first part, compared to the movies we're getting recently this is a must go cinema experience.
Loved the movie but the 3D at Film Alley was very poor!
Of course,  the visuals were stunning. But the story line is old. Tired of angry men trying to take over the world.
Long, kind of boring.  All that $ spent, it was better than Dune... Which isn't Saying Much by me.
One of the best movies I've ever seen after 3+ hrs I was still wanting more
Great cinematography and if you like the first one , way of water is nearly as good. For me it was more sentimental.
Movie was AWESOME! The story line, the special effects everything was amazing, We saw it in 3d 4dx I felt like we were in the movie, It was magical! We LOVED LOVED it.
Loved it!!! Breath taking and story was amazing!

Unmitigated incoherent babble. The movie could have (and should have) been half the length. There's really nothing to the storyline or anything else in the movie that  makes it worth your money or (lots of) time

I did struggle with whether this was worthy of 5 stars.  It is a movie that, if you love movies, you absolutely should see this in the biggest format possible.  I watched this in Imax 3-D and it was well worth it.  The story telling is not awesome, but this is probably the best looking movie I have ever seen. Predictable plot, trite, cliche, with laughably bad dialogue.  60 minutes too long.   I screened it in imax 3D in hopes that would amplify the spectacle of it enough to make it worthwhile.  No dice. The movie was great. The best 3D film I've ever seen. The three hour run time flew by. The story and action were completely engaging.
Visually beautiful. Expect to cry thr last 30 minutes.  Hard to follow who is who. I had to review what happened in the first .

The story is quite similar withe the first version, but the setting is mainly under water. There is at least 45 minutes of Navi Forrest Tribe struggling to adjust with the water environment, including facing prejudice, fight and bullying from the Water Tribe. 
The scene, the CGI and the battle scene is fantastic.

No question, visually fantastic.  Every image is a colourful, beautiful, and amazingly executed artificial reality.  Action scenes were well executed, with some really thrilling moments.

Biggest issue: Just too long.  There's a whole subplot about the children trying to fit in with the youth of the clan they moved in with, that just dragged the movie down.  Could easily have trimmed off an hour, and made the experience far more enjoyable.

They also replaced the human greed motivation from the poorly explained "Unobtanium" in the first movie to "magic-rejuvenating-whale-brain-juice" (wish I was kidding), that came off awkward and forced.

However, if you're looking for pure cinematic spectacle, much like the first one this sequel is at the top of the list of movie going experiences.
Amazing movie, love it!

I RECOMMEND you to watch this movie if you ...
1. want to spend time more than 3 hours.
2. love NATURE and beautiful animals.
3. want to watch it but did not watch the previous one.
4. just love movies :)

For me, an uneducated and young dreamer for a film director,
several things from this movie "Avatar: The Way of Water" came to my mind.

1. CG is awfully amazing!!!
Even though I know characters are all made of CG, I thought they are real... The scene when characters are moving in the water was the most stunning scene for me.
2. The story is not extremely dramatic!
I could expect what to happen and how a character behave in the movie; still I couldn't take my eyes off the screen. It seems like all scenes are dedicatedly depicted in delicate ways (WOW)
3. Sound and music are well organized and make audience fall into the magical incidents.
I think the bgm used in Avatar 2 did play a great role in the movie. Every sound was enthralling and elaborate... Awesome :D
4. It's too loooooong....
If you plan to go to theater for this, you should take something soft to sit for your hip not to hurt lol

Summary: If you have ENOUGH time and a LITTLE heart to watch Avatar 2, just watch it :D
I loved the newest Avatar. The scenery was breathtaking and love the continued storyline!!

A Mish mash of stories that don't really have anything to do with each other. Characters that aren't particularly interesting. A lot of the plot just doesn't make sense and a rehash of the first movie. Visually beautiful. Far too long

This movie was amazing.

Aliens, T2 Judgment Day, Cameron knows how to make a sequel that stands on its own. And like Spielberg he understands film is a visual medium.  Avatar: The Way of Water is stunning with an extended action packed climax that masterfully uses tension and suspense building elements from the Abyss and Titanic in the new Avatar ocean world. Loved it.
Great movie keep you on your end of the seats

It looks great. But the story underneath the cgi is vapid, uninspired and doesn't hold up to any scrutiny. Given the years he's been working on it I was expecting something much better than this copy and paste nonsense.

Everything about it, the visuals and motion capture, the acting, the story, character personality and progression, the emotions you go through throughout the whole movie, the immersiveness, the action scenes, the emphasis on family, and many more aspects of the movie that are just fenominal. If there was a rating higher than 10/10, it would 20/10. It has everything you want and more in a movie. I've never had a number one favorite movie in my entire life, but this one would take that spot. 3 hours never felt so short. I know some people say that's too long of a movie, but if the movie has excellent story building, then I feel like they could make it so much longer. That is just my thought on that. Sorry for the long review, but all in all, the movie kept you engaged the whole way through and had me on the edge of my seat.

Latest technology, thrilling action and still enough room for emotions.
I wasn't sure if Avatar would work a second time, especially as the first movie has always left me a little disappointed when watching at home in comparison to my first watch in cinema.
However, despite not changing much from the initial recipe, "The Way of Water" works great. As many others, I was in awe for the entire runtime. There are some obvious plot tools, unfinished characters and missed opportunities to risk a little more, but I trust in further sequels to clean most of it up or give it the necessary meaning.

What on Earth was that all about.  Over 2 hours of fighting in an exotic setting, with a token spiritual aspect woven through now and then. 

I loved the first Avatar,  but this one is absolutely dreadful. 

There are some pretty scenes in between all the fighting, hence the 1 star. 

Our thoughts - 3 hours of your time is better spent anywhere else..  don't buy into the hype!

Bellissimo! Dal punto di vista grafico il film è una vera e propria rivelazione, i Na'Vi riescono ad essere plausibili e concordi con gli umani tanto da farmi pensare di essere io stessa con loro, nonostante ciò la trama era sovraccarica di informazioni e per questo a film concluso ai personaggi non veniva dato un vero e proprio finale.

Too long. Could easily have been 2 hours shorter and delivered the same simple plot where the "good guys" win despite it being entirely unrealistic. For the entirety of the movie I was rooting for the "bad guys" simply because of the obnoxious moral high ground the natives are given within the narrative, which played out more as a means to appease the deep seated guilt held within the collective unconcious of western society for it's crimes against aboriginal cultures the world over in days gone. This is mostly a visual spectacle with drawn out attempts to make you care about the characters and the inhabitants of the world, ignoring the fact that humans continue to wreak havoc due to the selfishness of the main protagonist who insisted on interfering and interbreeding with an alien race.
I loved the movie. But annoyed with the really loud pack of teens having a meeting in the back.

A very pretty, rehash of the original Avatar, and a massive waste of an opportunity.
Sure, the movie looks good, and there is stuff about the value of family, and teens coming of age, etc.  Okay, fine, yawn....  But then, it's time for "the message" -- OK, let the anti-white misandry begin... again....   Result - three hours and $20 I'll never get back. 
It's basically the same story as the first Avatar, and even with the same main antagonist!  "Why?", you ask, when the Sci-fi genre is so wide open to new unearthly concepts, ideas and story-lines?  Don't know....  Let's just stick with bumbling evil white military that's ineffective against blue stone-agers with bows and arrows on pterodactyls..., because James Cameron is a creative genius, don't you know.... 
Again, we have the evil, mostly white, male, humans (and I remember one Asian guy and one white female) against the blue people and the Gaia.  All driven by vendetta, greed, prejudice, etc., oh, and a small mention that the Earth is dying.  "Why?", you ask.  Because humans ruined it of course!  Again... how original!
On top of that, because the movie is so contrived around "the liberal message", I found it hard to develop any real sympathy for the blue people, or for any of the characters, even the whales.  Although, I was able to develop some sympathy for the audience, having to sit through 3 hours of this woek rehash....
Honestly, this movie should have been called, "Pandering on Pandora", since apparently pandering to "the liberal message" is it's primary goal, and it does so in spades.

This was practically a repeat to the first movie.  Nothing new to advance the story.  They even figured out how to recycle the villain from the first Avatar movie.  The visuals were nice, but didn't make up for the exact same plot from the first movie.

Let's get the most obvious out of the way... The visual effects in this movie are absolutely amazing. I've really never seen its equal. I was blown away at how beautiful every single thing in the movie is. I went in knowing it would be killer, but it did surpass my expectations.

  Now, to the movie and story. It was just more of the same. There was not a moment in it where I was surprised, or some major jaw dropping twist. It played out just like most of us figured it would. Same story as the first, this time it revolved around the water (which again was beautiful.)

  There really was a point, somewhere in the middle of the movie, that I realized if I were going to watch the whole movie, I would have to work to do so. It just didn't grab me and hold on. A viewer should never have to work and to fight, to keep their attention on a movie, the movie is supposed to do that.

  It wasn't terrible, but it wasn't good either. It was somewhere in the middle. Had the CGI not been amazing, I wouldn't have made it through the movie. But I do believe, for most movie goers, they will find a fun time, and a tidy story. That is, if the length of the movie, doesn't turn out to be the thing that causes them to drift off into a daydream.

Avatar: Way of the Water is a wonderful continuation of James Cameron's popular Avatar series of films.  The first film was about discovery and love, whereas the new film is about family and protecting that love.  The first film had the viewers flying through the trees but the new film takes movie goers on an adventure to the water people of Pandora.  Jake and his family must settle into their new life on the run, while being hunted by the Avatar clone of their past enemies.  The action is gripping and the visuals are stupendous, I almost forgot I was watching a film that used mostly computer aided visual performances.  This film connects how important our world relies on other species, both on land and in the sea.  I look forward to the coming three films.  @jamescameronofficial deserves all the accolades, along with his behind the scenes crew.  The cast is simply brilliant and this level of computer aided performance is a game changer.

Avatar The Way of Water is one of the biggest sequels in the past decade or so, it's coming off the original Avatar, which is notoriously the highest-grossing film of all time. This was a massive task for James Cameron to pull off, and I think from a technical standpoint he was able to achieve his vision. This is one of the most beautiful films I've ever seen in my entire life, there are so many sequences that had me in awe, and I genuinely have zero clue on how they even made this movie. However, while I do think that this is better than the first Avatar film, it's not by a whole lot. Besides its gorgeous visuals Avatar, The Way of Water really does struggle at points to find its footing. It starts off pretty slow and gets better throughout each act, but these characters are still not as nearly as engaging as they should be. I am still not sold on Jake Sully as a protagonist whatsoever, he's got some badass moments here but he's pretty forgettable in this. His children are definitely the main focus here, and when the film fully focuses on them and their arcs I found myself much more engaged. I have somewhat similar feelings for this as I did for the first film, from a technical standpoint it's one of the best-looking films ever put to screen. Its visuals sell this movie alone and make this movie way better than it should be. But sadly due to some awkward dialogue, and characters that just feel redundant and generic, it loses some points here. But even with this said, I had fun watching and think there are more positives here than negatives, it provides a visual spectacle unlike no other and had me engaged even with this monstrous runtime. At the end of the day, I think the biggest thing I'll take away from this film is to not take movies like this for granted. This is probably the best-looking film ever made, it's the definition of a movie theater experience. I'm so grateful to embrace film in this current age through films such as this. Leaving the theater and entering the real world was a real bummer after visiting Pandora for three hours.
